Settlement.name: {=village_Iltanlar_1_1.name}Xamr-Argal
Settlement.text: {=village_Iltanlar_1_1.text}Usek sits at the foot of the Akkan hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.

Settlement.name: {=village_Iltanlar_1_3.name}Ebexun
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K1_1}Usek sits at the foot of the Akkan hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.

Settlement.name: {=village_Iltanlar_2_1.name}Orun
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K1_1}Usek sits at the foot of the Akkan hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.

Settlement.name: {=village_Iltanlar_2_2.name}Cilaxun
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K1_1}Usek sits at the foot of the Akkan hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.

Settlement.name: {=village_Iltanlar_2_3.name}Barsger
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K1_1}Usek sits at the foot of the Akkan hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.

Settlement.name: {=town_Lokti_1.name}Pilislinn
Settlement.text: {=town_Lokti_1.text}Tihr was once a fishing settlement of the Jumne, where settlers aimed for Rovalatys would come ashore. For some time, it was under the yoke of the Winlunding, whose migrations overwhelmed the Calradoi occupation. Nevertheless, some Jumne population already existed within the Ebor peninsula, and both populations were able to cohabitate. Yet, once the Jumne started another mass migration of their own, Tihr was taken from the Wilunding, and expanded into a great port of its own - the main destination for northern settlers to arrive in the continent. Today, the northern Ebor and most of the Bay of Sargot is controlled by Jumne chieftains.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_1_1.name}Loukis
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_1_1.text}Loukis sits by a flat plain next to Pilislinn. These plains were among the first lands to be colonized by the Lokti, after their migration from the east. Wheat is fruitful here, and the grain allowed Pilislinn to thrive into the capital it is.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_1_2.name}Avis-Uolinis
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_1_2.text}High on the Lokti mountains, folks at Avis-Uolinis raise sheep, to feed and clothe the freemen of Pilislinn. The sheep, a local breed, thrive on the grassy, rocky slopes of the mountain range, if not for the wolves and leopards.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_1_4.name}Zholes
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_1_4.text}Zholes is a solitary settlement of the Lokti, far west of the Lokti mountain range. The gentle curves of the soil make it unproductive for farming, but the vast sea of grasses allow northern steeds to thrive during the snow-free months.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_1_5.name}Manbat
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_1_5.text}Manbat lies within the dark pine forests of the Lokti. Villagers here hunt in the Vakken tradition, experts of the northern forests.

Settlement.name: {=town_Lokti_2.name}Kalnis
Settlement.text: {=town_Lokti_2.text}Kalnis was one of the first Lokti settlements since their migration from the east. The city lies on a naturally fortified position, with mountain streams and green fields to nurture its population.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_2_1.name}Kvieshi
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_2_1.text}Kvieshi is a Lokti settlement where villagers grow and harvest wheat during the summer to sell at Kalnis. The harsh temperatures and eastern winds make growing impossible during the winter.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_2_2.name}Purvis
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_2_2.text}Purvis lies at the base of the Lokti mountains. Mountain streams gather here into a marshy and muddy soil, making it good for flax growth.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_2_3.name}Kárvis
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_2_3.text}Kárvis lies at the southern edges of the Lokti flatlands, where the green pastures meet the dry steppes. Villagers here raise steppe cattle for milk and meat during the winter.

Settlement.name: {=village_Lokti_2_4.name}Raubat
Settlement.text: {=village_Lokti_2_4.text}Raubat is a mining settlement of the Lokti. The village lies on the mountain slopes, where the Lokti found iron within the rock, essential fuel to the daily economy of their towns.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Lokti_1.name}Mishkalinn
Settlement.text: {=castle_Lokti_1.text}Mishkalinn is a fortified settlement by one of the forested valley near the Lokti mountains. Tales tell it was once a Vakken forest-fort. Nevertheless, it is today fully assimilated into the Lokti realm, who have blood ties to the Vakken, but follow their own ways.

Settlement.name: {=village_castle_Lokti_1_1.name}Kylamishka
Settlement.text: {=village_castle_Lokti_1_1.text}Kylamishka is a Lokti settlement deep in a forested valley. Villagers here are descendants of the Vakken to the south.

Settlement.name: {=village_castle_Lokti_1_2.name}Purvis
Settlement.text: {=village_castle_Lokti_1_2.text}Purvis lies on the edge of the Lokti forest. Here the humidity gathers in a bog, which combined with the flat soil makes it fruitful to grow flax.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Lokti_2.name}Sendnar
Settlement.text: {=castle_Lokti_2.text}Sendnar, once a Jumne settlement, sits by the northernmost shores of the continent, at the origins of the Byalic peninsula. Named after the black sands of its cliffs, Sendnar is now populated by the Lokti, who settled in the nearby mountains. Trade relations with the Jumne are still maintained, though most Jumne settlers these days ignore the Lokti shores, in favor of the warmer Calradian shores to the west.

Settlement.name: {=village_castle_Lokti_2_1.name}Hákarlar
Settlement.text: {=village_castle_Lokti_2_1.text}Hákarlar sits by the northernmost shores of the continent and at the origins of the Byalic peninsula. It was once a Jumne community of fishers, whose trade also involved whales and sharks.

Settlement.name: {=town_Isles.name}Bragantja
Settlement.text: {=town_Isles.text}Old Baraganthea was once a major part of the western hemisphere of the Empire. Constructed near Charasea and thus the Empire's political heart, the Biscan isles were thoroughly Calradicized long before the Internecine. Baraganthea was the epicenter of western trade, bringing in ships from north up to the Jumne, south, and west all the way to Balion. From the port city, this trade would flow east, towards the Perass, or vice-versa, from the Perass towards lands distant. Baraganthea thrived despite its limited farmable land, and was mostly secured from any armies large enough to sack it - such open sea logistics, not to mention the Biscan navy, would be a nightmare. Nevertheless, with the dismantling of the Empire, the city eventually fell to the Wilunding, though not violently.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Isles.name}Poncta Bisco
Settlement.text: {=castle_Isles.text}At first a lighthouse, Poncta Bisco eventually became a minor port and outpost for the Biscan navy. Today it is a small fortified town, nested on top of the highest hills of the isle it controls. Much of the land is rugged and unfit for farming. Instead, islanders practice animal husbandry, specially that of cattle, a long tradition of the Biscan isles. Though not a major port as Bragantia, Poncta Bisco serves as an important buffer for the city, allowing ships to be deployed even if Bragantja was completely surrounded.

Settlement.name: {=village_Isles_1.name}Orula
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=village_Isles_2.name}Praja Salga
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=village_Isles_3.name}Barranco
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=village_Isles_4.name}Cerro Gaado
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=village_Isles_5.name}Outeiro
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=village_Isles_6.name}Vineas d'Illa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Massa_1_1.name}Atfarida-Ansaus
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Massa_1_1.text}Atfarida-Ansaus catches fish between Xarakut and Gothau’h. Traditions says it was here where the Massa first landed, finding their divinely promised land to settle on.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Massa_1_2.name}Triweinis
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Massa_1_2.text}A Massa settlement, folks at Triweinis collect wood for Xarakut. Though wood is plentiful, most of it is not adequate for walls or longships, and instead only wastes away their time and axes.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Massa_1_3.name}Stadeis
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Massa_1_3.text}Stadeis lies on a clearing near Triwandeis. The gentle slopes allow raising horses, and the distance to the woods keep beasts away. Horsemanship is a typical tradition of most Wilunding peoples, including the Massa.

Settlement.name: {=town_Massa_1.name}Gothau’h
Settlement.text: {=town_Massa_1.text}Watching over a large sand bay, Gothau’h lies on the northernmost entry of the Ansiwe Fragifts peninsula. The city was the first walled settlement of the Massa within the peninsula

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_1_1.name}Atisk
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_1_1.text}Atisk is a farming settlement of the Massa, growing crops on one of the few large open plains of the peninsula, otherwise covered by thick and dangerous rainforest.

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_1_2.name}Araaran
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_1_2.text}Araaran was a small settlement of locals, until the Massa moved in with their families. Villagers raise sheep by the hills, relatively safe from the rainforest predators.

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_1_3.name}Eisarn-Bairgahein
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_1_3.text}Eisarn-Bairgahein sits in the mountain valley east to Gothau’h. Here an abundant iron vein is used by the Massa for their weapons, tools, wagons and ships. Mostly covered by flat, wooded fields, iron is otherwise scarce and valuable in the Ansiwe Fragifts peninsula.

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_1_4.name}Triwandiuza
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_1_4.text}Triwandiuza is the deepest Massa settlement within the rainforest. Settlers here learned from the Widugauja how to hunt down the forest beasts. Such exotic pelts and feathers fetch high prices in the Perassic markets.

Settlement.name: {=town_Massa_2.name}Xarakut
Settlement.text: {=town_Massa_2.text}Xarakut lies in the souterhnmost settled bay of the Ansiwe Fragifts peninsula. The second city founded by the Massa, Xarakut was named after Sargot, which was said to be a great city with its own bay. Yet, much unlike the original Sargot, Xarakut is surrounded by warm, deep rainforest - not at all like the chilly and windy shores of the Varcheg bay..

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_2_1.name}Mathl-Fiskans
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_2_1.text}Mathl-Fiskans lies by the southern shores of the Ansiwe Fragifts peninsula, near Xarakut. The warm waters have abundant fish of many kinds, many of which the Massa had never seen.

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_2_2.name}Tweihnai-Triweinana
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_2_2.text}Tweihnai-Triweinana sits between patches of wood on the slopes near Xarakut. The Massa here collect the abundant wood, essential to their livelihoods.

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_2_3.name}Widusweina
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_2_3.text}Widusweina lies by the treeline near Xarakut. Here the Massa brought the Wilunding tradition of raising pigs, who thrive on the abundant foliage and fruit of the rainforest, if not for the beasts that hunt them down.

Settlement.name: {=village_Massa_2_4.name}Swammos
Settlement.text: {=village_Massa_2_4.text}Swammos lies in a clearing within the woods near Xarakut. The water collects here into a bog, making the land fruitful for flax. Artisans at Xarakut process it into linen to be worn throughout the Massa realm.

Settlement.name: {=town_Jumne_1.name}Hórstathr
Settlement.text: {=town_Jumne_1.text}Hórstathr in a heat pocket within the Byal peninsula. Here the snows make away for a brief farming season, and a dark pine forest. The town is mostly inhabited by Jumne, who are said to have founded the city themselves. Hórstathr is also the seat of power within the Byal peninsula, making the Thegn of Hórstathr effectively a petty-autocrat. Distant from the excitement of trade routes and the heat of wars, the inhabitants' main concerns are the cold, bears and the increasingly influential criminal mafias within the city.

Settlement.name: {=village_Jumne_1_2.name}Grónnvollr
Settlement.text: {=village_Jumne_1_2.text}Grónnvollr lies on the core of the Byal peninsula, in a heat pocket protected from the northern winds. The plain fields here, exempt of permafrost, allowed the Jumne to grow and sow wheat, a very desirable ability within the north. This grain allows Hórstathr to exert power over the peninsula.

Settlement.name: {=village_Jumne_1_3.name}Járnar
Settlement.text: {=village_Jumne_1_3.text}Járnar lies west of Hórstathr, in the high plateaus of the Byal peninsula. The Jumne here found an iron vein, common in the mineral richy, rocky peninsula.

Settlement.name: {=village_Jumne_1_4.name}Fúna
Settlement.text: {=village_Jumne_1_4.text}Fúna lies on the core of the Byal peninsula, in a heat pocket protected from the northern winds. Villagers hunt foxes, wolves and deer for their elegant furs, much sought after by the traders that come from the south.

Settlement.name: {=village_Jumne_1_5.name}Svartavitha
Settlement.text: {=village_Jumne_1_5.text}Svartavitha lies on the core of the Byal peninsula, in a heat pocket protected from the northern winds. The Jumne collect pine from the black forest, necessary to build and heaten their homes.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Jumne_2.name}Hraukr
Settlement.text: {=castle_Jumne_2.text}Byalakort is an Jumne colony in the southern edges of the Byal peninsula. Though the terrain is rocky and cold, the hardy Jumne still prevail, living off fishing and herding. Folks often cross the Byalic sea and climb up towards Sibir for trading.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Jumne_2_1.name}Sauthavollr
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Jumne_2_1.text}Sauthavollr lies on the plateau of Hraukr, the High Rock. The Jumne raise sheep, naturally adapted to the rocky terrain. No part of the sheep are left unused: wool, meat and milk are harvested, for the cold peninsula is unforgiving.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Jumne_2_2.name}Fjávollr
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Jumne_2_2.text}Fjávollr lies on the plateau of Hraukr, the High Rock. The Jumne raise their hardy northern cattle here, which feeds on the grasses of the plateau during its long summer. During winter, some of the cattle will be slaughtered for meat and to preserve hay.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Jumne_1.name}Byalakort
Settlement.text: {=castle_Jumne_1.text}Byalakort is an Jumne colony in the southern edges of the Byal peninsula. Though the terrain is rocky and cold, the hardy Jumne still prevail, living off fishing and herding. Folks often cross the Byalic sea and climb up towards Sibir for trading.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Jumne_1_1.name}Vík
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Jumne_1_1.text}Vík is where the Jumne first landed on the southern Byal shores. Experts in fishing, they first settled here before moving inland. At times, villagers also catch whales that drift into the Byal sea, providing Byalakort with whale oil.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Jumne_1_2.name}Ullbjarg
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Jumne_1_2.text}Ullbjarg lies north of Byalakort, on the heights of the Byal peninsula. Jumne colonists herd sheep on the hard yet grassy, uneven terrain, providing the town with both food and wool.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Jumne_1_3.name}Lágrbjarg
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Jumne_1_3.text}Lágrbjarg at the bottom of the southern Byalic cliffs. In the forests here, the Jumne found an iron vein deep within the rock, which they use to forge their weapons and tools.

Settlement.name: {=castle_V5.name}Kalbékkr
Settlement.text: {=castle_V5.text}Kalbékkr lies at the very tip of the Ebor peninsula, overlooking the northern sea. Here the Jumne reconstructed the town on top of ruins of the Calradoi, that date back to their attempts of colonizing the peninsula. Overlooked in comparison to the rich plains of central Calradia, where the empire plunged its war machine into, the peninsula never was much inhabited by the Calradoi. With the fall of the western provinces and the migration of large fleets of Jumne towards the continent, Kalbékkr, the cold stream, is one of the most targeted destination (after Tihr) for Jumne looking for a new home in the promised land.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V5_1}Tirby
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V5_1}Tirby sits in the cold misty waters that lie off of the Ebor peninsula. The low-lying lands on the northern side of the Ebor are suited to the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V5_2}Sirindac
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V5_2}Sirindac lies beneath the high ridges of the Ebor peninsula, somewhat sheltered from the bitter winds blowing out of the northwest. Migrants come here from across the Vlandian lands to prospect for silver in the mountain streams.

Settlement.name: {=town_Tihr.name}Tihr
Settlement.text: {=town_Tihr.text}Tihr was once a fishing settlement of the Jumne, where settlers aimed for Rovalatys would come ashore. For some time, it was under the yoke of the Winlunding, whose migrations overwhelmed the Calradoi occupation. Nevertheless, some Jumne population already existed within the Ebor peninsula, and both populations were able to cohabitate. Yet, once the Jumne started another mass migration of their own, Tihr was taken from the Wilunding, and expanded into a great port of its own - the main destination for northern settlers to arrive in the continent. Today, the northern Ebor and most of the Bay of Sargot is controlled by Jumne chieftains.

Settlement.name: {=village_Tihr_1.name}Haen
Settlement.text: {=village_Tihr_1.text}Haen is today an Junme settlement. They collect timber for the construction of longships at Tihr, essential to the Junme trade and warfare.

Settlement.name: {=village_Tihr_2.name}Kohaga
Settlement.text: {=village_Tihr_2.text}Kohaga was built by the Wilunding, but then colonized by the Jumne, and sits on the edge of the Ebor peninsula. Villagers here raise hardy northern cattle, brought by the Junme longships. Such northern Calradian pastures seem warm in comparison to their own.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_1_1.name}Tervas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer sits on the steep pass cut by the upper Trand river that climbs the Uchalion plateau. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_1_2.name}Kettulande
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer sits on the steep pass cut by the upper Trand river that climbs the Uchalion plateau. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Vakken_2.name}Kurava
Settlement.text: {=castle_Vakken_2.text}Kurava is a forest fort of the Vakken, situated in the heart of the Ircaran wildlands. The nearby woods are populated by Vakken folk, while the plains are mixed in with the Sturgiski. In their tongue, Kurava stands for 'muddy', alluding to the humid terrain around the Miron river and the streams running down the Ircaran stony hills.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_2_1.name}Irkaraa
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Vakken_2_1.text}Irkaraa sits in a broad forested valley looking down on the Galcha river. Vakken folks in these parts are expert trappers, hunting marten, fox and rabbit for the rich pelts much demanded in the southern markets. The region, Ircaran wildlands, is named after this ancient Vakken settlement.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_2_2.name}Bakeko
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Vakken_2_2.text}Bakeko lies next to the Miron river, on the slopes of the river source. Bakeko, meaning a Sturgiski ship, is named after the river ships carrying the locally produced iron towards trade hubs such as Epicrotea. The settlement was first founded by Sturgiski colonists, who were allowed to explore the Ircaran lands in an alliance between the Sturgiski and the chieftain of Kurava.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_2_3.name}Robatch
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_Vakken_2_3.text}Robatch lies on a clearing within the Ircaran wildlands. Here colonists cut down trees and planted grain instead, fruitful in the flat terrain blessed with streams from the hills. The settlement was first founded by Sturgiski colonists, who were allowed to explore the Ircaran lands in an alliance between the Sturgiski and the chieftain of Kurava.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Vakken_3.name}Karalinna
Settlement.text: {=castle_Vakken_3.text}Karalinna is the most isolated forest-fort of the Vakken. It lies on the edges of the Karakaz forest, far from the wars in the Calradian core lands. The Vakken have found little resistance in these cold forests surrounded by open plains and permafrost hills, up until the large scale migration of the Devsegs, now organized around the Khuzaits. Nevertheless, their distant position and fierce resistance of their sacred woodlands have kept them unsubdued so far.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_3_1.name}Karakyla
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer sits on the steep pass cut by the upper Trand river that climbs the Uchalion plateau. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_3_2.name}Karapuu
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer sits on the steep pass cut by the upper Trand river that climbs the Uchalion plateau. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Vakken_4.name}Vanninlinna
Settlement.text: {=castle_Vakken_4.text}Vanninlinna, or Vanni's fortress, is a forest fort of the Vakken. It is said in a distant past, a northern adventurer named Vanni settled with the Vakken tribes here. For his strength and justice, he was made chief. Today the Vanninen rule over Vanninlinna, and claim to be his descendants.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Vakken_4_1.name}Musta
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer sits on the steep pass cut by the upper Trand river that climbs the Uchalion plateau. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Darshi_1.name}Ahankalat
Settlement.text: {=castle_Darshi_1.text}Ahankalat, the iron fortress, was founded by the Darshi in the lower hills of the Kohi Rohini. The fortress oversees an extensive mining operation. The soil here is crimson red due to its extensive iron richness, which the Darshi mine and send back to their cities. These hills, however, are also fertile and able to provide farmland and pastureland, a valued resource around the Kohi Rohini.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_1_1.name}Ahanduwin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Darshi_3.name}Kan-Me-Ki
Settlement.text: {=castle_Darshi_3.text}Kan-Me-Ki is the northernmost Darshian palace within the thin but precious tract of land between the Darshian rivers. The fortification is the gateway to their precious farmable land, and thus is kept well-maintained and garrisoned at all times by the Shah.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_3_1.name}Gana-Gestin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Darshi_4.name}Sang-Ha-Pand
Settlement.text: {=castle_Darshi_4.text}Sang-Ha-Pand is a relatively new fortification of the Darshi, meant to protected the paths near and across the Nahr al-Kals. Near the fortified town the Darshi also explore minerals, such as the dry, whiteish limestone east of the Nahr al-Kals.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_4_1.name}A-Gig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_4_3.name}Lajan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Darshi_5.name}Kan-Abak-Gal
Settlement.text: {=castle_Darshi_5.text}The Gate of the Great Sea, Kan-Abak-Gal is the southermost Darshi fortification within the Kutshak Darya. The fortification lies by the sea shore, controlling who goes up or down the water. It feeds on the farms that lie on the green plateau of the region.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_5_1.name}U-Gal
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_5_2.name}Sisi-U
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Darshi_6.name}Gal-Kug-San
Settlement.text: {=castle_Darshi_6.text}Gal-Kug-San is an ancient noble palace of the Darshi. Constructed upon a hill, the fortification oversees vast farmable land between the Darshian major rivers. Its dominant position forces both caravans and enemy hosts to go through it first, before they reach the great Darshian cities.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_6_1.name}A-Gestin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_7_2.name}Kaspum
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_Darshi_8.name}Azn-Rod
Settlement.text: {=castle_Darshi_8.text}A fortified town by one of the Teyagh estuaries, Azn-Rod oversees the drylands east of the sacred river. Constructed by a patch of fertile grasslands, the town is fed by local grain farms and its flax industry, which grows abundantly in the marshy riverbanks. The Darshi consider this the last point before the Kohi Rohini, and often the royal retinues of the Shahanshahs would gather here before venturing towards the Devseg, upon which they would bring down their swords against either rebellious petty shahs or nomadic khans looking for a land to call their own khanate.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_8_1.name}Henun
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_Darshi_8_2.name}Huruum
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=town_Darshi_1.name}Ur
Settlement.text: {=town_Darshi_1.text}Ancient Ur lies at the shores of what the Darshi now call Darya Kutshak, the Small Sea. The city is built by the mounth of the Upeyratu, the sister river to the Teyagh, so large that its suburbs occupy both shores of the great river. The root of its ancient walls lie deep within the ground, and many a time such walls were tried by barbarians and nomads. Ur withstood them all, and now hosts the largest and oldest temple of the Immortal Flame. Within its great walls, artisans of great skill have persisted a myriad of traditions - from carpet making, to pot making and silk weaving. Its great harbors, split between both sides of the river, receive great trade from lands far to the south, as well as trade boats from upstream that bring Calradian goods all the way from the Tanaesis shores. Ur is the capital and pride of the Darshi, and to this day hosts a great amount of their population.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_1_1.name}A-sha
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_1_3.name}E-Tur
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_1_4.name}Umah
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=town_Darshi_2.name}Urukur
Settlement.text: {=town_Darshi_2.text}Founded countless generations ago, Urukur was mayhaps built by the ancestors of Thuran, the Darshian Shah that founded Hubyar. Urukur was but the first of such Darshi colonizations to the west, through which they sought to control the lands and trade of the Perass, otherwise separated to them by great mountain ranges. Urukur lies on a high and fertile plateau, where great farms and ranges livestock thrive amidst the lush and tall grass, though still mostly absent of trees. It was here that they first established contact with the Nahasawi, most of them still but nomads at the time, otherwise known as Jawwal. Though positive scouting and trading relations were at times established, the Darshi were quick to judge the Nahasawi inferior - barbarians that relied on nomadism, with no great Shah to speak of. As such, the Darshi enslaved and subdued many of the Jawwal banu, creating a deep resentment within the Nahasawi. For this reason, they still name the mountains of Urukur as Jabal Ashabi - the 'Mountains of the Masters'. This hatred culminated into the murdering of Thuran by Asera, the patriarch that united the banu.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_2_1.name}A-Dam
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_2_3.name}Gana-Il
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=town_Darshi_3.name}Rod-Ha-Sray
Settlement.text: {=town_Darshi_3.text}Rod-Ha-Sray lies on the hills east of the Teyagh, where tributaries merge towards the sacred river. Its palace is detached from the city, surrounded by the waters and rock from all sides, making it exceptionally hard to conquer. Many a Sharab who ruled from this palace felt confident to question their Shah.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_3_1.name}Xurmay
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_3_4.name}Rautazamig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=town_Darshi_4.name}Urnab
Settlement.text: {=town_Darshi_4.text}Second only to a few, Urnab is one of oldest settlements within the Darshi plains. The city lies between the Kutshak Darya and the Namak Darya - the Small Sea and the Salt Sea. Many a fishing and trade ship pass by its harbours, which are overshadowed only by the harbours of Ur. So ancient is Urnab that its founding is long forgotten by the Darshi, and many a folk story and religious poem features the city in their tales. Like every Darshi city, Urnab hosts a temple to the Atash Amesha, the Immortal Flame, which glows brightly during the night, announcing to any incoming ship that the law of the Flame is upheld over all others.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_4_1.name}A-Mun
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_4_3.name}A-Shesh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_4_4.name}Kallakalla
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_4_5.name}Nakur
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_5_1.name}Mu
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_5_1.text}Mu lies on the southern shores of the Kutshak Darya. Folks here grow crops on the bountiful land, blessed by sediments that stream down from the Upeyratu.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_5_2.name}Eanshe
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_5_2.text}Eanshe is named after the donkeys traditionally raised here. The village lies on the bountiful shores of the Kutshak Darya, and has been a place of raising equines for countless generations.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_5_3.name}Aduru
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_5_3.text}Aduru sits on the base of the southernmost hills of the Darshi. Here the gentle slopes are well prone to certain eastern spices, which the Darshi have learned to cultivate. Such spices are much sought after, both within and without their realm.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_5_4.name}Ganagig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=town_Darshi_6.name}Shahr-Ap-Got
Settlement.text: {=town_Darshi_6.text}The city of the rivers, Shahr-Ap-Got lies on the hills where three tributaries of the Teyagh origin. Covered by the tributaries in the back and slopes all around, the city is a formidable defensive position. In ancient days, such advantage was surely used in the struggles between petty shahs, now long forgotten thanks to the legitimacy of the royal dynasty. Though caravans come from the east and the ample plains of the south, most of the Upeyratu and Teyagh trade do not pass through Shahr-Ap-Got.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_6_1.name}Hurgig
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_6_1.text}Hurgig is a date plantation settlement of the Darshi. Folks grow date trees by the water, a strong flux caused by the merging of three smaller tributaries..

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_6_2.name}Udun
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_6_2.text}Udun lies on the riverbanks of the Teyagh. Here the elevated position is advantageous for gathering and collecting clay brought by the water from great distances. Such clay is sold and manufactured into fine pottery at the shops of Shahr-Ap-Got.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_6_3.name}Idadug
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_6_3.text}Idadug lies on the eastern hill slopes of Shahr-Ap-Got. The water-rich soil here is propicious for tall grasses, shrubs and sparse woodlands, but most importantly, spice shrubs. Such condiments are much sought-after throughout the continent, but only in such Darshi sun-bathed hills they can prosper.

Settlement.name: {=town_Darshi_7.name}Kohi-Pand-Sray
Settlement.text: {=town_Darshi_7.text}Kohi-Pand-Sray overlooks the green valley between the Kohi Rohini and the southeast mountains. It was through these mountains that many a barbarian horde came to raid the Darshi lands, making the city pivotal as a defender of the Teyagh. Additionally, the local exploration of silver and wood are both greatly valued in the region. Though the city lies distant from the political heart of the Darshi, its governors must be carefully managed by the Shahanshah, lest they think themselves too rich and independent to serve their rightful ruler.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_7_1.name}Gishduq
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_7_1.text}Situated in a especially fertile field, Gishduq is an ancient farming settlement. Folks here grow grops on the flat plains and drink from the mountain streams that flow into the valley. Such farming feeds the city of Kohi-Pand-Sray.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_7_2.name}Gishburu
Settlement.text: {=village_Darshi_7_2.text}Lying at the base of the southeastern Darshi mountains, Gishburu collects the local wood, otherwise quite scarce in the region. It is decreed by the Shahanshah that they shall not exaggerate their industry, such that the woods can continue to be extracted.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_7_3.name}Urudu
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_Darshi_7_4.name}Ukur
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A10_1.name}Esi Noog
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A10_2.name}Gaar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A10_3.name}Kul Kojir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A11_1.name}Koir Ju
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A11_2.name}Dok
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A12_1.name}Halif
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_A12_1.text}Halif lies close by the Perassic lagoon of the Sarrani lands. Traditionally, cattleheads and raised here and allowed to graze on the open grassfields. This practice was started by the Kannan, who brought such cattle across other coasts of the Perass where they made their colonies and the land was adequate.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A12_2.name}Shurab
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_A12_2.text}Shurab is one of the most ancient fishing communities of the Perass. Settled by the first generations of the Kannan, Shurab has ever since been a source of local fish, and at times crocodile. Perhaps it was here that the Kannan first made their unbreakable cultural and religious connection to the Perass.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A1.name}Shuron
Settlement.text: {=castle_A1.text}Shuron is a fortified town of the Kannic, at the very tip of where the Nahasa touches the ocean. Originally a fishing hamlet, it now guards the last of the Kannic, beaten by the Nahawasi and Calradoi. Shuron lies by the sea, folks farm dates, raise sheep by the hills, but mostly catch fish.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A1_1}Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A1_2}Fanab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_3}Fanab sits in a low promontory between the bay that the Aserai call the Gulf of Shariz and the inner sea of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The seawinds bring just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.

Settlement.name: {=village_Kanic_1_1.name}Yrzit
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_Kanic_1_2.name}Arszit
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_Kanic_1_3.name}Arsalp
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=town_Geroia_1.name}Zaharra Gero
Settlement.text: {=town_Geroia_1.text}Earliest of the Geroiaci ports, Old Gero is likely the most ancient settlement of man within the Geroian isles. It was here that the Calradoi found the native islefolk and began their settling, which proceeded without great resistance. Many a ship has sailed throug Gero's ports, likely the most well-known port in the continent, and many a slave left one of those ships to never set sail again. Though once an imperial province, Gero eventually became independent from the empire, likely between succession turmoils that occupied the legions. With their vast and experienced fleet, Gero was able to remain independent, capitalizing on its advanced and well-established trade connections. By becoming an independent merchant city, Old Gero paved the way for a new future for the isles.

Settlement.name: {=village_Geroia_1_2.name}Putetxe
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.

Settlement.name: {=town_Geroia_2.name}Perassia
Settlement.text: {=town_Geroia_2.text}Named after the Kannan word for the Calradian sea, Perassia was the second large port of the Geroiaci. Despite Gero's headstart, the economic heart of Geroia eventually moved to Perassia, which outgrew the old capital in population. Centered at the very heart of the sea trade, Perassia has an unbeatable trade advantage. Many a time the city was besieged for its strategical value, but the Geroiaci have endured. It was through Perassia's port that the Vine Goddess cult - the goddess of war, trade and the sea - entered the Geroiaco belief, having been transported by the Kannan ships.

Settlement.name: {=village_Geroia_2_1.name}Jauregi Herria
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.

Settlement.name: {=village_Geroia_2_2.name}Mahastxi
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.

Settlement.name: {=village_Geroia_2_3.name}Gatzadartza
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.

Settlement.name: {=town_Geroia_3.name}Giatacitte
Settlement.text: {=town_Geroia_3.text}Latest of the Geroiaco ports, Giatacitte dominates the eastern isle of Geroia. Despite its highly rocky nature, the isle is still valuable as a trading outpost. Folks here rely on local sheep, fish and food imports, paid for through the toll revenues and salt mines driven by slave labour.

Settlement.name: {=village_Zendar_1.name}Provaton
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.

Settlement.name: {=village_Zendar_2.name}Laspodis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN1_1}Varagos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN1_1}Varagos sits on the Aris river, a small highland stream that flows into the deep pool known as the Ophthys. The land here is not especially rich, but is sufficient for the raising of sheep.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EN2.name}Limnon
Settlement.text: {=castle_EN2.text}Limnon is a fortified settlement by the shores of lake Lakonis. It was once a city-state of the Lakonioi, who allied themselves with the Calradoi in their struggle against the Palaicoi. For their willingness to welcome the Calradoi, there was no bloodshed once the imperial dragons flew over the town walls. The town is today thoroughly Calradicized, and the port on the placid waters of the Lakonis take in ships of the Sturgiski laden with fur.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN2_1}Lochana
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN2_1}Lochana sits on the eastern shore of Lake Laconis. The muddy, low-lying land here is well suited to the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN3_1}Rhesos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN3_1}Rhesos sits in a plateau in the Dryatic mountains. Highland cattle thrive on the grasses of the heights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN4_1}Gaos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN4_1}Gaos sits in a broad valley in the Myzead, the hill country in the east of the empire. Nomadic herders once occupied this land, and the village's name is taken from their word for cattle.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EN5.name}Nevyarela
Settlement.text: {=castle_EN5.text}Nevyarela, erected between Saneopa and Argoron, was long ago founded by the Lakonioi. Often, the Lakonioi would violently clash with the Palaicoi, who inhabited the mountains both east and west of the Lakonioi plains. Once the Calradoi came, the Lakonioi were quick to ally them, and eventually be completely assimilated.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN5_1}Atrion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN5_1}Atrion in the valley of the Nevys, a cold, slow-moving river that drains into Lake Laconis. The level, wet land here is fine for the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EN6.name}Ari Kastron
Settlement.text: {=castle_EN6.text}Ari Kastron was built by the Aris river, overlooking a valley that goes deep into Dryatic terriroty. The Kastron acted as a base of operations to legions subduing the Dryaticoi tribes, a deed that always costed them much blood. Today the fortified town watches over silver and cattle settlements, who occasionally are harassed by small warbands. Moreover, with the dismantling of the Empire, the kastron controls a narrow passage between the northern and western empire factions, which is also the main, safest route between both realms. Today the kastron is considered to have much strategic value.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN6_1}Ataconia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN6_1}Ataconia sits on a plateau in the piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The people of this area are skilled at finding seams of silver ore exposed by the streams rushing down from the mountains.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EN7.name}Ponum Kastron
Settlement.text: {=castle_EN7.text}Ponum Kastron is one of the most important fortifications of the Calradoi northern border. The fortified settlement guards the land bridges to the Sturgiski realm, as well as the northernmost connection to the Devseg plateau. With the dismantling of the Imperium, both foreign threats now seek to prey upon the infighting Calradoi.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN7_1}Epinosa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN7_1}Epinosa lies in the far north of the Empire, just south of the glacial lakes known as the Iltan portages, where ships are hauled between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. The region is relatively thinly populated, but large herds of cattle graze on the green downs.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN7_2}Pons
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN7_2}Pons is one of the northernmost settlements of the Empire. It is named for the 'crossing' of the Iltan portages, a network of glacial lakes that allow ships to be hauled between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. The region is relatively thinly populated, but large herds of cattle graze on the green downs.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EN8.name}Rodagora
Settlement.text: {=castle_EN8.text}Rodagora was once a fortified city-state of the Lakonioi, who embraced the Calradoi and accepted their rule. The city thrived before it fell to ruins, perhaps by the struggle between the Calradoi and the Darshi, who expanded their domain across the Tanaesis. Yet the Calradoi made sure to rebuild and populate the town, and it greatly served them in keeping the Devseglar across the river. Rodagora protects iron mines and wood harvesting areas, essential to fuel the military engine of the fortification.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN8_1}Syratos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN8_1}Syratos at the base of an escarpment just north of Lake Tanaesis. Villagers mine the hills above them, where cold winters crack the stone to reveal fine seams of iron ore.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN8_2}Tememos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN8_2}Tememos lies in heavily wooded hill country at the northern end of Lake Tanaesis. Many of the villagers work as foresters, harvesting oak, beech and pine for the sale to the lake cities.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN9_1}Mecalovea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN9_1}Mecalovea sits overlooking the Galchasic Cataracts, a series of rapids and waterfalls through which the Miron river empties into Lake Laconis. The village, perched on a cliffside for protection from raiders in this frontier region, thrives on the ore deposits exposed where the cataract cuts through the escaparment.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN9_2}Agalmon
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN9_2}Agalmon sits near the juncture of the Galchas and the Miron, two small but fast-flowing northern rivers. This foresting village has had mostly good relations with its Sturgian neighbors thanks to decades of intermarriage, though they have become strained of late with the outbreak of war.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN1}Epicrotea
Settlement.text: {=n9WMUuSp}Epicrotea, the 'All-Conquering' was named after the eccentric long-haired military genius Sarapios, who crushed a Battanian host and secured the lands west of Lake Laconis for the Empire. Its towers, overlooking the Miron river, have frequently been a northerner's first glimpse of the awesome and terrible force to their south.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN1_1}Marathea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_1}Marathea lies on a narrow shelf of land between the Miron river and Mount Aracathos, the tallest peak in the Dryatic mountains. The villagers are skilled miners, extracting iron ores from the nearby cliffside.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN1_2}Stathymos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_2}Stathymos lies in a narrow valley beneath a towering ridge of the Dryatic mountains. The highland streams wash fertile soil down the hillsides, making this district one of the breadbaskets of the imperial north.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN1_3}Gymos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_3}Gymos is a quiet fishing village in the Diathmic Bay, on the far west of Lake Laconis. Villagers harvest pike from the bay's deep waters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN3_2}Dyopalis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_4}Dyopalis lies in a valley in the Dryatic mountains. Despite the cold winters, the region's fertile soils make this district one of the breadbaskets of the northern Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN2}Diathma
Settlement.text: {=wKMo2CUP}Diathma, the city of the Divine Decree, was erected by an imperial general on the ruins of a Dryatic shrine overlooking Lake Laconis. It was the last stand of the Dryatics, the northernmost of the Palaic peoples, who rebelled against the Empire and were overcome. According to legend they were pushed back into the shallows of the lake and fought until they were exhausted and the bloody waters engulfed them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN2_1}Alosea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN2_1}Alosea lies near the entrance of the Diathmic Bay, on the far western end of Lake Laconis. The folk of this region live well off the pike and sturgeon of the lake.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN2_2}Jeracos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN2_2}Jeracos sits in meadowland in the northern piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The climate, kept mild by the lake breezes, makes for good horse breeding.

Settlement.name: {=village_EN2_3.name}Leukys
Settlement.text: {=village_EN2_3.text}Leukys sits in meadowland in the northern piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. Here the Calradoi started the exploration of the Dryatic limestone, necessary for them to settle into the region with permanent garrisons.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN5_2}Masangara
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN2_3}Masangara sits on the banks of the Nevys, a cold, slow-moving river that empties into Lake Laconis. Cattle are raised here in former marshy woodlands, now drained and turned into meadows.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN3}Saneopa
Settlement.text: {=EJZLzhJk}Saneopa sits on a low pass leading from the Nevys valley to the north to the pool of the Ophthys. The ancient Palaic peoples of this region, like the Battanians, treated lakes as sacred sites, and the Ophthys in particular was said to be a gateway to another world. The hustle and bustle of Saneopa, one of the main trading centers of inland Calradia, stands in sharp contrast to the dark and silent waters below.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN3_1}Enoisa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN3_1}Enoisa sits by the shores of the Ophthys, the eye, a deep lake in the hill country south of the Dryatic mountains. Wheat grows here, fed by the ample rains of the north. Legend has it that this was once a shrine of the ancient Palaic people, who believed the lake was a gateway to another world.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN1_2}Aeoria
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN3_2}Aeoria sits in the fertile Vale of the Aris, in the heartland of the Empire. The dialect here is laced with words from Palaic, the language spoken in the center of the continent before the Empire came.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN3_3}Crios
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN3_3}Crios lies nestled amid the limestone ridges of the eastern Dryatic mountains. The highland soils make fine grazing for horses.

Settlement.name: {=village_EN3_2.name}Calcys
Settlement.text: {=village_EN3_2.text}Calcys lies nestled amid the limestone ridges of the eastern Dryatic mountains. The Calradoi collect the limestone here, necessary to settle the mountains occupied by barbarians.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN4}Argoron
Settlement.text: {=LqPJY4s9}The city of Argoron sits where the cold, slow moving Nevys River meets Lake Laconis. This was once the land of the Laconians, who saw the Empire as a protector against the more warlike Palaic peoples. They welcomed and intermarried with imperial settlers and their chiefs joined the Senate, and their old language and customs faded away.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN6_2}Potamis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN4_1}Potamis sits in a valley in the lower Dryatic mountains. The people of these parts have raised cattle since pre-Calradic times, and its milk and butter are sought out by traders and travellers passing through the region.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN4_2}Alatys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN4_2}Alatys lies on the flat southern end of Lake Laconis, on delta lowlands formed by the River Nevys. The waters of the lake, which are very shallow and muddy here, are well-stocked with flounder and crayfish, while trout can be fished in the Nevys upstream.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN2_2}Nortanisa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN4_3}Nortanisa is a fishing village on the southern shores of Lake Laconis. Villagers plac nets and cages in the shallow edges of the lake to catch roach, bream, perch, and crayfish.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN4_4}Hetania
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN4_4}Hetania sits beneath a spur on the far northeastern bend of the Dryatic mountains. As in many villages around here, the foresters of this region still speak the Palaic languages of the tribes who lived here before the Empire came.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN5}Myzea
Settlement.text: {=8UJ3cPrZ}Myzea gives its name to the Myzeiad, the rich hill country of the east-central empire. This region is the old stomping grounds of the senator Litos, who brought the Palaic tribes here into the empire relatively peacefully by offering them protection against raiders from the steppes. When he fell afoul of his rivals in the Senate, however, he tried to organize them into a rival 'barbarian' republic modelled on the ancient Calradian version. The empire snuffed it out, but the people here, now thoroughly Calradicized, still harbor an attachment to the old republican system and its partisans.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN5_1}Vealos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN5_1}Vealos sits in the slowly rising eastern slopes of the Dryatic mountains in the eastern reaches of the Empire. Although mostly covered with beech and oak woods, the mountain slopes provide good grazing for horses and has traditionally been home to stud farms for the imperial cavalry.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN5_2}Orthra
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN5_2}Orthra, a relatively recent settlement, was named by an imperial captain after the dawn for its fine eastward views of the Myzead, the hill country of the eastern empire. It was founded as a stud farm to breed imperial horses with steppe stock from the east, and continues to provide horses for the imperial cavalry.

Settlement.name: {=village_EN5_3.name}Myzeonix
Settlement.text: {=village_EN5_3.text}Myzeonix sits on the slopes of the Myzeiad. Good stone from the Myzeaid rocks gather here, which the Calradoi started collected at the time of Litos, as the newly annexed Myzea required the touch of civilization through expert marble masonry.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EN4_2}Themys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN5_3}Themys lies under a ridge of limestone crags in the Myzead, the hill country of the imperial heartland. The grasses on the rolling downs are well-suited to the raising of sheep.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN5_4}Samatha
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN5_4}Samatha sits upon a sloping ridge in the sun-drenched highlands of the Myzead. The hillsides have been terraced to allow the growing of mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested, placed in vats and fed to silkworms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EN6}Amprela
Settlement.text: {=YYYxOiCq}Amprela is the foremost town of the far northeast of the Empire. Watchmen stand atop its towers, looking out for beacons from the frontier fortresses to the north, east and west that might signal the approach of raiders. Horse archers recruited from the rough Eleftheroi freemen drink in the barracks, waiting for the order to ride out against horsemen from the steppe. Cataphracts sally through its gates to vie with the princes of Sturgia for control of the trade crossing the nearby network of lakes known as the Iltan portages.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN6_1}Avasinton
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN6_1}Avasinton sits in the wilder eastern reaches of the Myzead, the hill country of the central empire. Villagers have cleared away the thickets and thornbrush of this region, including the pungent wormwood after which the village is named, to allow the growing of mulberry bushes, the leaves of which are harvested and fed to silkworms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EN6_2}Boreagora
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN6_2}Boreagora lies in the cold north of the Empire, by the network of glacial lakes known as the portages of Iltan. Nearby imperial forts, looming over the waterways, keep watch for Sturgian and Khuzait raiders. The lowlands here are suited to the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EW1.name}Nova Lysiapalis
Settlement.text: {=castle_EW1.text}Nova Lysiapalis lies on the western shores of the Empire. This fortified polis once patrolled the bay of Charasea, the Calradoi capital. Now, it lies somewhat forgotten, in comparison to its former importance, as the Calradoi fight their internecine, far away from the old capital.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW1_1}Garontor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW1_1}Garontor gives its name to the promontory between the Gulf of Charas and the inland Perassic sea. Coastal meadows, where tall grasses tolerant of the ocean salt-spray thrive, support the rearing of fine horses.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EW2.name}Ariopalis
Settlement.text: {=castle_EW2.text}Ariopalis is built near a steep ridge in the Aris valley. This favourable defensive position allows them to only worry about attackers from one side. From this position, they oversee and protect the numerous grain farms in their immediate vicinity.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW2_1}Thorios
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW2_1}Thorios sits in the Aris valley in the heart of Calradia. River irrigation and the relatively warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district, along with neighboring Bergum, feed much of the central empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW2_2}Bergum
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW2_2}Bergum sits in the Aris valley in the heart of Calradia. River irrigation and the relatively warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district, along with neighboring Thorios, feed much of the central empire.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EW3.name}Iltaramea
Settlement.text: {=castle_EW3.text}Iltaramea lies on the northern shores of the Perassic. Imperial citizens enjoy a warm southern wind. Ships oft travel back and forth from the Geroiaco isles, at times laden with slaves. Iltaramea was founded by the Calradoi, watching over a gap of the Iltaric hills that connects the Perassic to Poros and the imperial heartlands. At one point, southern raiders would come ashore here, traverse the forest and hills in secret, until they found the peaceful farmlands of the interior, hopelessly undefended.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW3_1}Onica
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW3_1}Onica lies on the northern shores of the Perassic sea. The hills of this district are terraced with the olive groves for which the southern Empire is famous, producing a light, fragrant oil.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EW4.name}Koursionea
Settlement.text: {=castle_EW4.text}Koursionea lies on the northern edge of the Cursion escarpment. Some say it was the first Calradicós settlement east of the Gulf of Charasea. An ancestral version of the Kastrons, Koursionea secured the path eastwards through the south of the Cursion, as its northeastern path was never secured for long. Right by the Cafalcombe, the highlands north of the Cursion were always violently disputed with the Battaniaidd, often in their favor. For this reason, Koursionea never prospered much, and instead served as a buffer between the Imperial capital province and the fierce highlanders.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW4_1}Thractorae
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW4_1}Thractorae sits on a small bay that feeds into the larger Gulf of Charas. These lands, stirred by hot winds from the south and watered by hillside springs, have been used by imperial landowners for the experimental growing of date palms.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EW5.name}Garyarea
Settlement.text: {=castle_EW5.text}Garyarea was an ancient Kastron constructed by the Calradoi.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW5_1}Veron
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW5_1}Veron in the foothills of the Uchalion massif, near the headwaters of the Garys river. On summer nights the hills above the village are dotted with the fires of shepherds, taking their animals to graze on the upland pastures.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW5_2}Goleryn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW5_2}Goleryn sits in the warm, oak-covered Epiric hills, near both the Vlandian and Battanian frontiers. Sheep-raising is a way of life in these parts, as is sheep-rustling.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EW6.name}Erythryarea
Settlement.text: {=castle_EW6.text}Erythryarea lies at the base of the mount Erithrys, sacred to the Calradoi. Because of this sanctity, the Calradoi have not further urbanized the mount, instead keeping watch for the Battaneid, who often delve into the deep woods that surround the mount. Erythryarea itself lies on a patch of open plains, surrounded by farms, olive and grape plantations the Calradoi carved out of the woods.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW6_1}Hertogea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW6_1}Hertogea lies in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a huge basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. Villagers grow olives on the slopes leading up the mountain.

Settlement.name: {=castle_EW7.name}Ortysiulapalis
Settlement.text: {=castle_EW7.text}Ortysiulapalis lies on the eastern shores of the Bay of Ortysia. This fortified town oversees Calradoi settlements in a small, green peninsula, separated from the mainland by a mountain range. Due to the presence of Ortysia, its naval trade relevance is little. For this reason, folks have adopted the name 'Little Ortysia' for their polis.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW7_1}Oristocorys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW7_1}Oristocorys sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Early morning sea-mists from the west and the hot sun of midday allow the growing of wine grapes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW7_2}Elvania
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW7_2}Elvania sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Olive trees grow on the slopes of the nearby hills, warmed by the southern sun.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW8_1}Gersegos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EW8_1}Gersegos sits in the gorges of the Miron river, as it cuts between the cliffs of the Cursion Escarpment and the Dryatic mountains. Villagers have sunk mines into a spur that overlooks the village, extracting silver and other precious metals.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW1}Lageta
Settlement.text: {=ZAGUIKOn}Lageta was infamously acquired by the Empire by an act of treachery. A rogue imperial mercenary murdered the Palaic chieftain who employed him, took the citadel, invited in imperial colonists, then bequeathed the town to the Empire. The Senate disavowed his action but accepted the bequest. The district is now thoroughly Calradicized, but the Battanians to the north remember, and whenever an imperial envoy speaks of the sanctity of treaties and pacts, they just nod to each other and say, 'Lageta.'

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW1_1}Primessos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_1}Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW1_2}Montos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_2}Montos sits at the base of the Cursion escarpment, near the Battanian frontier. The foresters here keep a watchful eye on their neighbors, always looking for raiding parties coming westward from the valley of the Miron river to their east.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW6_2}Nideon
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW1_3}Nideon sits on a low-lying meander of the Zeos river, in the shadow of the plutonic Mount Erithrys. Flax grows in fields reclaimed from the river marshlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW2}Zeonica
Settlement.text: {=kghCLS9q}Zeonica sits by the seaside at the base of the Iltaric hills, a land of wine, grain and horses. It was named for the Lady Zeona, one of the few women to rule the Empire - admittedly as regent for her son rather than Empress Regnant. It is known for the Zeonic Wind, a gale that blows northward across the Perassic Sea every summer carrying the burning heat of the Nahasa desert to the imperial south. In other seasons the weather here is mild, a weather pattern that has provided many a poet with a metaphor for the transience of passion.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW3_2}Tarcutis
