Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW2_1}Tarcutis sits on the shores of the Perassic sea. The sandy soil and morning mists, channeled by offshore islands, allows the growing of grapes overlooking the beaches.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW2_2}Neocorys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW2_2}Neocorys, the new village, sits in gently sloping land in the Temea valley cleared only recently of forest. The local landowners have established stud farms, supplying horses to the imperial cavalry.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW2_3}Alsasos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW2_3}Alsasos sits in the west end of the Temea, a broad valley north of the Perassic sea. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW2_4}Zeocorys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW2_4}Zeocorys at the foot of the Ilataric hills, running along the southern coast of the Empire. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW3}Jalmarys
Settlement.text: {=TI3fS2xN}Every realm has a city whose inhabitants are mocked for their provincial unsophistication, and for the Empire that city was Jalmarys. One of the first imperial colonies established inland of the Perassic Sea, it served the Empire as a base to subdue the western Palaic tribes. Paravenos was happy to accept the plunder and slaves sent to them from its garrison, but snickered at them behind their backs. That changed when the Jalmaryan general Carsos staged a military coup. When a senator, stymied by his thick accent, nervously asked him to repeat a decree, he unsheathed his sword and said, 'Do you understand this?'

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW4_2}Gamardan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW3_1}Gamardan sits at the head of a small bay that branches off the larger Gulf of Charas. The wines of this region are unusually sweet and strong, and valued throughout the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW3_2}Aegosca
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW3_2}Aegosca sits at the head of the Temea, a broad valley in southern Calradia. Though named for the goats that used to roam this region, the landowners have turned over the pastures to the raising of far more profitable horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW3_3}Dradios
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW3_3}Dradios sits by the Lesser Amynis, a tributary stream of the Aminys river that rushes down from the heights above. Villagers divert the mountain streams to irrigate their rich grainfields.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW4}Ortysia
Settlement.text: {=JhBSnWAe}Ortysia, named for the quails who inhabit the nearby coastal marshes, was the first Calradian colony on the shores of the Perassic Sea. In its early centuries, it fell under the authority of the Kannic city-state of Quyaz, but the empire's expansion soon united the colony with its mother republic. For centuries, sailors coming from the pirate-infested islands of the Bay of Charas gave thanks when they saw its towers looming through the haze of the western Perassic, signalling a return to safe imperial-patrolled waters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW4_1}Arpotis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW4_1}Arpotis sits on a high bluff overlooking the confluences of the Aminys, Gavys and Zeos rivers. The sides of the hills are terraced to grow wheat, with cisterns to catch the rain blowing up from the sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW1_2}Lysia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW4_2}Lysia gives its name to the narrow strait where the Perassic Sea joins the western ocean. It lies just on the Perassic side of the straits, near broad beaches that allow the farming of salt.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW4_3}Vinela
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW4_3}Vinela sits beneath the waterfalls where the Aminys river rushes down to join the Perassic Sea. Villagers collect salt from the sea in the shadow of coastal cliffs.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW4_4}Garengolia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW4_4}Garengolia lies near a rich vein of silver in hills overlooking the Gavys river. The Empire have minted its denars from these mines for centuries.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW5}Amitatys
Settlement.text: {=rX8oGVvV}The Palaic chieftain of Amitatys had a particularly grim reputation, a tyrant who slaughtered innocents to appease the gods of the underworld in the hope they would grant him immortality. Inevitably, he fell into conflict with the Empire, and during the siege an earthquake crumbled his walls and allowed imperial troops into the city. More died in the ensuing sack than the tyrant had ever killed, but it was war, and the outcome - attributed to the wrath of Heaven - was a staple of imperial propaganda as they expanded their foothold in the region.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW5_1}Elipa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW5_1}Elipa sits near the upper reaches of the Aris valley. These sunny, well-watered highlands are one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW5_2}Phasos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW5_2}Phasos sits amid rolling chalk hills between the Temea and Aris valleys. The rich grass of the down is some of the best horse-breeding land in the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=village_EW5_3.name}Péthra
Settlement.text: {=village_EW5_3.text}Péthra lies next to the mountains that shield Amitatys. Villagers here gather stone from the mountain base, much needed for Calradoi infrastructure.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_EW6}Rhotae
Settlement.text: {=5SpYVtie}Rhotae is a former Palaic hill-fort in the shadow of the basalt slab of Mount Erithrys, once known as Rotash. It fell to the Empire shortly afer Lageta. The Palaic chief here, when he heard of what happened to his neighbor, slaughtered a dozen imperial citizens under his protection. The eccentric long-haired general Sarapios led the punitive column that took Rotash and burned it to the ground. 'Lageta we took treacherously but with little bloodshed. Rotash we took honorably, with great bloodshed,' he supposedly said afterwards. 'Both will be remembered as a stain on our name. The victor always takes the blame, but keeps the gold.'

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW6_1}Carphenion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW6_1}Carphenion lies in the wooded highlands between the great basalt slab of Mount Erithrys and the Dryatic mountains. The villagers raise cattle in the highland pastures.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_EW8_2}Vathea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW6_2}Vathea sits high on the slopes of the Dryatic mountains, facing across the valley to the great basalt slab of Mount Erithrys. The villagers mine iron from shafts sunk deep into the cliffs of the mountains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW6_3}Thersenion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW6_3}Thersenion sits in the upper Aminys valley, in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a great basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. This district is one of the grain breadbaskets of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_EW6_4}Leblenion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EW6_4}Leblenion lies alongside the Aminys river in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a great basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. This district is one of the grain breadbaskets of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=castle_ES1.name}Kalsaropalis
Settlement.text: {=castle_ES1.text}Kalsaropalis is a small Calradoi fortified town next to the Calsa river. Mostly isolated from main trade routes, folks here live a relatively quiet life, making their humble livelihoods while buffered from the fronts of war. Trade goods, such as grain and hardwood, are shipped downriver to Danustica and beyond.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES1_1}Odrysa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES1_1}Odrysa lies on the far eastern frontiers of the Empire, just across the River Tiagys from lands that are now the Khuzait Khanate. Though this area is dry, oak and other trees grow in the Tiagys gorges and other nooks in the hills, sustaining a small lumber industry.

Settlement.name: {=castle_ES2.name}Tanaesaefinis
Settlement.text: {=castle_ES2.text}Tanaesisfinis lies at the crossing between the Tanaesis lake and the Tyagis river. The fortified town watches over the crossing to Transtanaesia, an old Imperial province now occupied by the Khuzaits. The town is also important for control of the river trade downstream, towards Danustica and the Darshi.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES2_1}Corenia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES2_1}Corenia is one of the farthest flung villages of the empire to speak the Calradic tongue. It sits in the plains southeast of Lake Tanaesis in the shadow of the Akkan Hills, beyond which is spoken only Darshi and the languages of the steppe. Villagers grow grain here, keeping watch for raiders from across the frontiers.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES2_2}Metachia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES2_2}Metachia is the lies on the southern shores of Lake Tanaesis in the frontier lands beyond River Tiagys. This imperial colony, established in more peaceful times, is a center for mulberry bushes used in silk production.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES3_1}Melion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES3_1}Melion in a narrow valley near the center of the Myzead, a rugged plateau in the east of the Empire. Villagers here cultivate mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested and fed to silkworks, producing thread much valued by both refined imperial nobles for their courtwear and hard-riding nomads and frontiersmen, who wear it beneath their armor as an extra layer of protection against arrows.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES3_2}Sagolina
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES3_2}Sagolina sits at the foot of a narrow valley in the Myzead, a rugged plateau in eastern Calradia. The silver mined from nearby hills helps explain the effort and expense to which the Empire has gone in past centuries to conquer and defend these lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_1}Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES4_2}Ethemisa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES4_2}Ethemisa sits on the river that the Aserai call the Nahr al-Kals, the Bitter River, and what imperial citizens call the Calsa. Here, the river has just descended from the coastal hills and has not yet reached the alkali plains of the southeast. The lands around produce a fine crop of grain.

Settlement.name: {=castle_ES5.name}Gorsethyarea
Settlement.text: {=castle_ES5.text}Gorsethyarea is a fortified town of the Calradoi. The garrison here mainly watches over the river, which once used to be the main pathway of southern raiders towards Calradoi heartlands. Ample fresh water and arable fields make the citizens of Gorsethyarea mostly unpreoccupied, if not for occasional levies to serve in the southern and eastern fronts.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES5_1}Morenia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES5_1}Morenia sits overlooking the Sethys river, on a low pass leading over the hills to the valley of the Lycarea. Villagers collect clay from the riverbanks for the kilns of the imperial southlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES6_1}Sestadaim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES6_1}Sestadaim sits on the western side of the great Ornian rock, an outcrop in the center of the Lycarea valley. Some say the vultures for which the rock is named once gathered here to feast on the bodies of those who died working the local silver mines.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES7_1}Jogurys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES7_1}Jogurys lies on the flat western shores of Lake Tanaesis. This land was originally inhabited by nomadic tribes and has come under cultivation only recently. Imperial colonists have made intensive efforts to grow mullberry bushes here to raise silkworms, a lucrative product in this region.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES8_1}Chanopsis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ES8_1}Chanopsis sits near the headwaters of the Sethys river in the plateau region known as the Myzead. Wheat grows well on the sun-baked plains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES1}Danustica
Settlement.text: {=xkkI7ejQ}The frontier city of Danustica dominates the network of lakes and lagoons known as the Calsea. It has long held the line against incursions by the Aserai and various Darshi shahs and padishahs further to the east. Many an imperial legionary stationed here has scribbled graffiti on its walls cursing the city's sweltering summers, brackish water and the mosquitos that rise from the Calsea, but the inhabitants are proud of their role as border defenders and mock the soldiers wilting in the heat around them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES1_2}Caira
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_1}Caira sits amid the network of rivers, lakes and lagoons known as the Calsea. Any further east, the land becomes alkaline and barren, but here the floodplains of the parallel Calsa and Tiagys rivers allow the growing of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES1_2}Polisia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_2}Polisia sits among the network of rivers and lakes known as the Calsea near the Aserai borderlands. Villagers harvest salt from a lagoon to their west, a former inlet of the Perassic sea that was cut off by a sandspit. These lowlands are shunned by many others in Calradia, who find the air thick and fetid, but the inhabitants are proud of their role keeping watch on the Aserai.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES1_3}Tegresos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_3}Tegresos sits just north of the River Calsa, right before it enters the network of lakes, creeks and lagoons that form the borderlands with the Aserai. The inhabitants of this region have bred sheep that feed on marsh-grasses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES1_4}Erebulos
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES1_4}Erebulos lies by a lagoon that was formerly part of the Perassic Sea, closed by a recently formed sandspit. Villagers scoop clay from the creek-bottoms here, selling it to the pottery kilns of Danustica and other nearby towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES2}Vostrum
Settlement.text: {=ytBRXqt8}Vostrum was founded by the Calradian mercenary Archacos, one of a number of rogue commanders who broke away from the empire during its expansion. Unlike some, who tried to reproduce the empire's republican heritage, he chose to rule as a god-king. His dynasty lasted for generations, until imperial troops overran it and smashed every haloed statue of Archacos and his successors into rubble. Even today, western and northern imperial senators accuse families from this region of being closet monarchists.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES5_2}Atphynia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES2_1}The village of Atphynia sits near the mouth of the Sethys river, just before it splits into three to form the valley known as Tripotamia. Villagers here have laid out salt pans near where the Sethys estuary joins the Perassic sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES2_2}Gorcorys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES2_2}Gorcorys sits on the Gorea, the southernmost tributary of the Sethys river in the valley of Tripotamia. The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES2_3}Avalyps
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES2_3}Avalyps sits near the headwaters of the River Calsa in the warm coastal hills of the southern Empire.The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES2_4}Alision
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES2_4}Alision lies on the northern coast of the Perassic Sea. Though fishing is poor in these parts, villagers have constructed salt pans that stick far out into the shallow waters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES3}Poros
Settlement.text: {=rGXdJybe}The town of Poros sits near the northern shores of the Perassic Sea. The warm rolling hills of these parts are well suited to the raising of sheep and horses. The herdsmen have a reputation for being proud and violent, but the nobles of the Leonipardes clan who rule this land are careful to respect their autonomy. Livestock rustling and blood feuds are common here, and it is said that the Leonipardes will never interfere unless invited by both parties, but when they do, their judgments will be obeyed by all.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES3_1}Canoros
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES3_1}Canoros sits in the flat southern reaches of the Lycarea plain. This land has been good horse country since even before the Empire came, furnishing the steeds of the Lycarean riders who routed several Calradian armies before their final defeat and absorption into the imperial cavalry.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES3_2}Tevea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES3_2}Tevea sits where the plains of Lycarea slowly ascend to meet the base of the Ornian Rock. They raise sheeps on the slopes of this massive outcrop, named for the vultures who glare down from its heights onto the hazy flatlands below.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES3_3}Zestea
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES3_3}Zestea sits where the plains of Lycarea meet the coastal Iltaric hills. Sheep graze on the low slopes overlooking the hazy flatlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES4}Lycaron
Settlement.text: {=WGtzBswe}The natural fortress of Lycaron sits on a spur jutting out of the great Ornian rock. In the final years of the imperial conquest, the Palaic tribe here negotiated a peaceful federation with the empire, only to see their home seized by the rebel leader Gethuz. The ensuing siege was only the first of many that Lycaron would undergo in the ensuing centuries, as its nearby silver mines made it a prize for every imperial pretender who ever tried to seize power in a civil war. It is said that the colony of vultures who inhabit the upper reaches of the Rock have dined on the flesh of every people of Calradia.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES4_1}Sagora
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES4_1}Sagora on a low ridge in the middle of the Lycarean plain. This district is one of the rockier and less fertile parts of the plain, but the valley scrubs still supports the grazing of sheep.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES8_2}Popsia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES4_2}Popsia in a narrow canyon between the Ornian Rock and the valley of the Ophthys pool. Trees grow tall here in the cool shadows of the hills, and villagers harvest pines for sale as lumber.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES4_3}Canterion
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES4_3}Canterion lies in the east of the Lycarean plain. The slowly rising land here gets more rain than other parts of the plain, and the rich grasses have made it good horse country since even before the coming of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES5}Onira
Settlement.text: {=4ENGzVaC}The tale of Sarpea of Onira is one of the epic poems of the eastern frontier. Like many, it seems written to justify the Empire's conquest. Sarpea, a senator's daughter, was seized by a Palaic chieftain and carried to his citadel here. When the imperial armies appeared before its walls years later to rescue her, she begged them to retreat for the sake of her infant son, whom her fearsome husband had threatened to hurl from the walls instead of allowing him to be captured and raised by his mother's people. The legions withdrew, so the story says, but the boy grew into a warrior who joined the Empire and slew his father. It is now the center of a horse-breeding industry on the eastern plains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES5_1}Lanthas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES5_1}Lanthas in the broad plains south of Lake Tanaesis. This is good sheep country, but in a land scoured by imperial fugitives, wild Eleftheroi riders and steppe nomads, the villagers here have learned to watch their flocks closely.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES5_2}Lartusys
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES5_2}Lartusys lies near the southern end of Lake Tanaesis. The village sits near a deposit of salt, and salt springs occasionally bubble to the surface, feeding the legend that this was once a gateway to a haunted underground sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES5_3}Parasemnos
Settlement.text: {=village_ES5_3.text}Parasemnos sits close to a low pass linking the Tanaeitic plain with the valley of the Calsa river. The villagers collect wood from the ample woodlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES6}Phycaon
Settlement.text: {=RL2vacqv}Phycaon sits at the head of the Sethys valley, one of the main grain-producing regions of the central Empire. Once the largest of the Palaic cities, its leaders led a league of the tribes against imperial encroachment into the region. But when the empire's victory looked inevitable, they made their peace. The population, now thoroughly Calradicized, have a reputation for being serious, respectable and trade-minded, dependable if a bit humorless.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES6_1}Saldannis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES6_1}Saldannis lies beneath gypsum bluffs overlooking the River Sethys. The fine soil of the hills makes for a sticky clay when it washes down to the river, much prized by the potters of the imperial south.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES6_2}Spotia
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES6_2}Spotia lies alongside the gently flowing Sethys river. The low rolling hills of this district comprise one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=village_ES6_3.name}Zethakma
Settlement.text: {=village_ES6_3.text}Zethakma lies on a high plateau by the mountains next to the Sethys river. It is said the Palaicoi worshiped their gods here, until the peaceful annexation by the Calradoi. Ever since, the Calradoi moved in, and their expert masonry made good use of the stone deposits available. Over time, the Palacoi gods were forgotten.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES6_2}Amycon
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES6_3}Amycon lies in a series of small but sharp ridges between the Ornion Rock and the Aris valley. The people of this land are sheep herders, known for their dry, salty cheese flavored with cumin.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_ES6_3.name}Ornosos
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_ES6_3.text}Next to Ornosos, the Ornion rock a high plateau, unfit for growth of greens. Here rich marble is deposited, and the Calradoi were quick to find and make use of it to build their temples, villas and statues.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ES7}Syronea
Settlement.text: {=UHvEEEBb} Syronea sits on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis. This city, once peaceful and rich, was once a byword for luxury and decadence. This was the center of the Empire's silk industry and an entrepot for the goods flowing in from what was known as Transtanaesia, the imperial possessions and protectorates beyond the great lake. But the coming of the Khuzaits ripped the Transtanaesia from the Empire's grasp and the Senatorial families of Syronea were forced to relearn the arts of war, dusting off old gilded armors and sharpening bejewelled swords to lead their followers against Urkhun's warriors.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES7_1}Psotai
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES7_1}Psotai sits near the southern tip of Lake Tanaesis. The low-lying fields here are one of the major grain producing centers of the eastern frontier regions.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ES7_2}Vargornis
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES7_2}Vargornis is a fishing village on Lake Tanaesis. Huge pike can sometimes be found in the lake's waters, along with more common perch and bream.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ES7_2}Eunalica
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ES7_3}Eunalica sits on the western shores of Lake Tanaesis. This low-lying country is fine land for the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=castle_S1.name}Kongard
Settlement.text: {=castle_S1.text}Kongard is the westernmost fortification of the Sturgiski, nearly at the tip of the Kachyar peninsula. Though the valleys here are strait and the rocky soil is not very fertile, people here still thrive on fishing and herding. Being at the tip of the peninsula, Kongard is a prime destination for Jumne ships, be them peaceful or otherwise.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S1_1}Ustokol
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S1_1}Ustokol sits on the windswept Kachyar peninsula, between the Bay of Varcheg and the Byalic Sea. Hardy northern cattle have been bred to eat the short grasses that grow among the rocks, supplemented by sea-kelp in hard times.

Settlement.name: {=castle_S2.name}Zelenopol
Settlement.text: {=castle_S2.text}Zelenopol oversees the mountain passes between the core Sturgian lands and the eastern most edge of Tyal, the realm of the Vagiroving. The settlement first started as a trading outpost for the furs of the Vakken, who mainly occupy the northern woods.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S2_1}Mazhadan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S2_1}Mazhadan sits near the source of the Galchas river, just west of Lake Laconis. Villagers grow flax in the muddy valleys between the hills in this cold, rainy land.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S3_1}Nevyansk
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S3_1}Nevyansk sits on a flat shelf of land overlooking the Bay of Varcheg. The land is cold, but the runoff from the hills brings rich soil, and villagers grow hardy crops like rye and barley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S3_2}Dnin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S3_2}Dnin sits on pastures overlooking the narrowest part of the Bay of Varcheg. Horses graze on the heights, glancing down occasionally at the trading longships and fishing boats passing beneath them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S4_2}Ismilkorg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S4_2}Ismilkorg sits on grassy downs between the Galcha and Vastra rivers, two small tributaries of the Miron. The people here are mostly cattle-herders as well as cattle-rustlers, and have long traded raids with the imperial frontier villages to the east and Battanians to the west.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S5_1}Ov
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S5_1}Ov is a recent Sturgian colony in the Ircara wilds, a forest northwest of Lake Laconis. Villagers brave cold, wolves and the sometimes-hostile, sometimes-friendly peoples of the woods in pursuit of fur, the bounty of the northlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S5_2}Ferkh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S5_2}Ferkh lies at the northern edge of the Ircara wildlands, a forest northwest of Lake Laconis. It serves as a base for traders venturing deeper into the woods, brave cold, wolves and the sometimes-hostile, sometimes-friendly peoples of the woods in pursuit of fur, the bounty of the northlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S6_1}Takor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S6_1}Takor is a cattle raising village at the pass that the Battanians call Mynad Rhyfel, the mountain of war, and their imperial and Sturgian neighbors call Minador. It is one of the main trading and raiding routes between the wild north and the more settled imperial lands.

Settlement.name: {=castle_S7.name}Urikshal
Settlement.text: {=castle_S7.text}Urikshal oversees the very end of the Byal sea, neighboring the Sturgian town of Tyal. It is said a great warrior by the name of Urik came here with a host of his followers, and proclaimed the land his own. Local rulers, still of Jumne ancestry, claim to be his descendants. For the most part, the inhabitants of Urikshal prefer to trade and farm, but still hone their axes for war.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S7_1}Urikskala
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S7_1}Urikskala sits in the Portages of Iltan, a network of glacial lakes over which longships can be hauled and sailed between lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. Villagers net small spiny perch and crayfish in the shallow waters, drying them for sale to travellers.

Settlement.name: {=castle_S8.name}Iltaborg
Settlement.text: {=castle_S8.text}Iltaborg lies on the hills that overlook the Iltan lakes. The fortified town oversees the lowlands of mount Iltan, where the Sturgians, at times mixed with Jumne, have settled for cattle raising and foresting. The Iltan lakes provide a natural layer of protection from southern invasions, specially from the Calradoi, and the few land passes are patrolled by Sturgian riders. Folks here find special joy in the smooth, crystal blue surface of the lake.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S8_1}Vladiv
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_S8_1}Vladiv sits at the base of Mount Iltan, in a cold, dark wooded valley. The hardy cattle of this region have learned to dig through thick winter snows in search of grass to sustain them until the spring.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_S1}Varcheg
Settlement.text: {=i2VkRLBg}The former Nord colony of Varcheg sits on a windswept sea-bluff at the base of the Kachyar peninsula in what was once Battanian land. The jarl who founded this coastal outpost, hoping to trade with the interior, pledged himself in fealty to the Battanian High King Dernmachad, but then proceeded to dabble in Battanian politics. Annoyed, Dernmachad hired a Sturgian army to crush his unreliable new vassal. The Sturgians complied and routed the Nords, but then demanded the newly captured town as their payment. They called the town 'Varcheg,' a corruption of the Nordic term for 'oathsworn companion,' to mock both rivals whose quarreling had handed them their prize.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S1_1}Rodobas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S1_1}Rodobas, the house of Obas, is named for a long-dead Sturgian hill chieftain. Perched high on a ridge overlooking the wilds of Ircara, it serves as a base for trappers looking for furs in the dark woods below,

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S2_2}Forin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S1_2}Forin sits among rye and barley fields next to the Galcha river, on the edge of the Ircara wilds. The village thrives on the grain it sells to the woodland fur-trapping communities.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S1_3}Kargrev
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S1_3}Kargrev was once Car Gryff, the ringfort of the Battanian chief Gryff, but was conquered by the Sturgians two generations ago. It lies alongside the Bay of Varcheg, where the local fishermen take advantage of the relatively sheltered waters of the bay, where fish of many kinds come to spawn.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_S2}Balgard
Settlement.text: {=Xom9DeXZ}Balgard, which sits on the icy waters of Mazopor bay, was founded by migrants from the Nordlands. Legend holds that the initial wave of Nords arrogantly demanded tribute from the nearby Vakken and Sturgian tribes, who formed an alliance and drove the newcomers back to their ships. But the victors fell out over the spoils, until a canny Nord, Gundar, landed and volunteered to help them fairly divvy up the weapons and armor of his dead kinsmen. The residents recognized Gundar's lordship over the region and his descendants, intermarried with the Sturgians, are today the grand princes of Sturgia.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S2_1}Safna
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S2_1}Safna sits on a high ridge overlooking the rapids that link Lake Laconis to the narrow Mazopor Bay. Villagers rear cattle on the grassy shelfs overlooking the sea-cliffs.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S2_2}Marabrot
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S2_2}Marabrot sits on a high rocky ridge between the fjord known as Mazopor Bay and the Byalic Sea. This harsh land would probably not be settled where it not for the rich iron deposits in the hills.

Settlement.name: {=village_S2_3.name}Kamydorga
Settlement.text: {=village_S2_3.text}Kamydorg is halfway between Balgard and Kongard. Villagers here quarry from the steep valley walls, naturally rich in stone.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S6_2}Dvorusta
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S2_3}Dvorusta is a fishing village overlooking the rapids linking the Bay of Varcheg with Lake Laconis. Villagers make their way down the cliffsides at dawn to catch salmon leaping over the rocks, as well as herring and cod in the sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_S3}Omor
Settlement.text: {=pbHXtJ82}Omor sits on the eastern shores of Lake Laconis. Long before the Sturgians formed themselves into a principality it was a holy site for the forest tribes, who worshipped their gods and ancestors in the sacred oak trees of the nearby woods. Today, it is an emporium for fur trappers and woodsmen who prowl the Ircara wildlands to the east, and the primeval peace of the forests is drowned out by the sounds of bartering, saws, and the unloading of ships at the lake.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S3_1}Chornobas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S3_1}Chornobas, or Blackwood, sits in lands cleared from the forests overlooking the cataract through which the Miron river empties into Lake Laconis. The villagers grow rye and barley in fields misted by the spray from the falls.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S3_2}Skorin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S3_2}Skorin sits on a promontory separating Dyatom Bay from the wider Lake Laconis. Villagers pull both freshwater flatfish from the shallow bay waters and bigger catch, including pike, from the main lake.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_S4}Varnovapol
Settlement.text: {=aTMypBiY}Varnovapol, which sits beneath the Chertyg mountains on the crystal waters of Lake Laconis, has the dubious honor of being perhaps the most-often conquered city in Calradia. Originally it was a colony of the Empire, infamous as a place of exile for dissident senators, before it was seized by Nords as a base to expand their influence into the Sturgian fur trade. It was taken by the Alkit tribe from the eastern steppe and briefly served as the capital of a small khanate, before finally falling to the fierce Ormidoving clan.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S4_1}Borchovagorka
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S4_1}Borchovagorka sits on a small rise on the steep northern shores of Lake Laconis. The village depends primarily on fishing, pulling perch, bream, salmon and occasionally large sturgeon and pike from the lake waters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S8_2}Glavstrom
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S4_2}Glavstrom sits beneath Mount Iltan, a craggy peak in eastern Calradia named for a god of the steppe peoples. These wild lands abound with fur-bearing marten, fox, rabbits and other animals.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S4_3}Omkany
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S4_3}Omkany lies where the Lake Laconis coastline rises up to meet the icy Chertyg mountains. Villagers in this district raise hogs, curing their fat with salt and in garlic and selling it throughout the northlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S4_4}Yangutum
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S4_4}Yangutum sits in a nook of the Chertyg mountains on the north shores of Lake Laconis. Villagers here have found iron ore deposits in the mountainsides.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_S5}Tyal
Settlement.text: {=F5HlQdgf}Tyal sits in the western foothills of Mount Iltan, on the eastern borders of the Sturgian lands. This region has long stood aloof from the power struggles of the other Sturgian principalities. Its people are known as wanderers, traders, horse breeders and fur-trappers. The local aristocracy has occasionally exchanged princesses with the steppe tribes to the east to firm up a truce or a trade pact, and proudly includes the names of several great khans on their list of ancestors.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S5_1}Visibrot
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S5_1}Visibrot is a sheep-rearing village on the lower slopes of Mount Iltan, just below the network of glacial lakes known as the Iltan portages. Though this region is cold and remote, its importance as a trade juncture between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis, between the Empire and the steppe, mean that it is relatively densely populated.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S5_2}Bukits
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S5_2}Bukits sits on the eastern slopes of Mount Iltan on the Khuzait frontier. Villagers raise highland cattle here, bred to withstand the icy gusts that tear down the mountain.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S7_2}Alov
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S5_3}Alov sits on the edge of the glacial lakes known as the Iltan portages. Villagers cultivate rye and barley on the high ground overlooking the lakes, and the rich black soil of the region compensates for the long winters and short growing season.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_S6}Sibir
Settlement.text: {=PPadNxa6}Sibir was founded in a dark valley amid the Chertyg mountains by Nordic traders, who wished a base to buy furs from the local Vakken-speaking foresters. As the Sturgian tribes became principalities, and elected chieftains evolved into boyars who demanded taxes and labor as their due, this region became a magnet for Sturgians who had little taste for deference. Today, the ambitious Isyaroving family governs this region, but they must always balance their hunger for wealth and men to fight their wars with their subjects' reluctance to provide it.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S6_1}Kvol
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S6_1}The villagers of Kvol raise small, sturdy cattle at the base of the Chertyg mountains. They include the descendants of refugees and malcontents from across Calradia, seeking isolation in the cold northern forests.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S6_2}Radakmed
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S6_2}Radakmed sits in a basin amid the Chertyg mountains. Villagers here grow flax in the marshy valley floor.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S6_3}Alebat
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S6_3}Alebat sits deep in the forests of northeastern Sturgia. This isolated region has long been a refuge for those fleeing oppression or debt or bloodfeud across the northlands, and the dialect is strongly influenced by the tongue of the Vanni woodspeople.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_S7}Revyl
Settlement.text: {=T2E4xKVn}Revyl, chief town of the rocky Kachyar peninsula, was a traditional rival of Balgard. According to legend the Balgardian princess Arkina, whose husband had been slain by the Revylians, accepted a proposal from her enemy's king to marry and settle the feud. On her wedding night, however, she barred the door of his hall and burned him and a hundred of his kinsmen and warriors alive inside. The feud has long since been settled by pacts and marriages with happier outcomes, although Revylians still resent the ascent of the Balgardian Gundaroving dynasty.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S7_1}Korsyas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S7_1}Korsyas sits near the narrowest part of the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers fish the waters to the west for cod, char, and other cold-water sea fish that venture into the bay.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_S7_2}Karbur
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S7_2}Karbur sits at a plateau on the Kachyar peninsula. Sheltered somewhat by a high ridge to their north, the villagers here raise barley and grain.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_S1_2}Zhemyan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_S7_3}Zhemyan is a fishing village at the northern shores of the Kachyar peninsula. Villagers brave the storms that sweep through the Byalic Sea to pull up ample catches of cod, char, and sometimes even small whales.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A2.name}Hasirit
Settlement.text: {=castle_A2.text}Hasirit lies on the fertile highlands of the Jabal Ashabi mountains. The exploration of grain farming here is ancient, and very valuable in this otherwise desert region. To the south, the Darshi have mastered their own patch of highland, making great open farms near Urukur. Hasirit was once under their influence, but now the fortification serves the Nahasawi.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_1}Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A2_2}Asmait
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A2_2}Asmait lies in a nook of the Jabal Ashabi mountains, bordered to the south by the deep desert. Villagers trap floods running down the hills during rare rainstorms, using the water to grow date palms and other crops.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A3.name}Bawwabat Balad
Settlement.text: {=castle_A3.text}Bawwabat Balad is a fortified town that lies next to the Damar river, with its back covered by one of the many escarpments of the Jarjara. The riverbank provides towns folk with ample farmingland, allowing full food independece for the town.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A3_1}Ain Baliq
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A3_1}Ain Baliq is clustered around a well in a wide valley that separates the Jarjara Escarpment from the Jabal Tamar mountains to the west. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A3_2}Deir Hawa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A3_2}Deir Hawa sits on the windswept southern shores of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. Villagers trap run-off water from the hills and grow flax in the lowlands here.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A4.name}Wahah Balad
Settlement.text: {=castle_A4.text}Wahahbalad lies next to a major, pristine oasis close by the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The access to fresh water and good farmland make it an obvious choice for settlement.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A4_1}Medeni
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A4_1}Medeni sits in lowlands between the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers grow dates by the coast in gardens watered by wells and small dams in the wadis that trap run-off from the cliffs during the short rainy season.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A4_2}Qidnar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A4_2}Qidnar lies in the floodplain of the Damar river, the most densely populated part of the Aserai lands, where it slices through the Jarjara Escarpment. Farmers here grow grain in the rich silt brought by the river's annual flooding.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A5.name}Memab
Settlement.text: {=castle_A5.text}Long ago founded by the Kannic, Memab, the rock by the sea, lies in the fertile valley of Qasira. As the legend tells, the great queen Eshora made the valley flourished with her magic, which she used to control the Jinn, spirits of nature, according to the Kannic. Memab protects the easternmost entry of this valley, much valued for its fertility. In typical Kannic tradition, even after the Nahasawi occupation, folks here maintain a naval custom.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A5_1}Jamayeh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A5_1}Jamayeh sits on the southern shores of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al Yeshm, the Jade Sea. The climate is well-suited to olive trees that thrive despite the short rainy season.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A6.name}Gadirits
Settlement.text: {=castle_A6.text}Gadirits is one of the most ancient colonies of the Kannic. Unlike most, it lies inland, guarding the land pass between the Kannic, mainland Calradia to the north and the Darshi riverlands to the southeast. Many a time the walls of Gadirits were besieged, specially once the Calradoi came, never allowing it to fully thrive into a metropolis. Its walls now serve the Nahasawi, who in their ambition betrayed the Calradoi and carved themselves a kingdom out of the southern provinces.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A6_1}Shibal Zumr
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A6_1}Shibal Zumr sits on the Nahr al-Kals, the river of lime. Here the waters are pure and the soil is fertile, and grain is grown. But a short distance to the south, the land becomes barren and alkaline, and only the hardiest crops survive.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A6_4.name}Ynis
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_A6_4.text}Settled long ago by the Kannan, Ynis is a traditional grape collecting community of their ancient society. The Kannan place a high value on grapes and wine, for they believe it to be a sacred fruit, the fruit of the Vine Goddess. This tradition has been continued by the societies that replaced the Kannan, as the land here is most suitable for the grape culture.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A7.name}Shurelit
Settlement.text: {=castle_A7.text}Shurelit, named after the Kannic goddess, lies on the rockfase of the westernmost escarpements of the Nahasa. Unlike most Kannic colonies, this fortified town lies high on the hills rather than on the shores of the Perassic. Here the plateau is rich in fresh water from the rock, allowing fruit, olives and sheep to thrive. Shurelit also guards the land connection between Quyaz and the rest of the Nahasa, long ago defending it from desert raiders.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A7_1}Uqba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A7_1}Uqba sits alongside the Perassic Sea. Villagers trap rainwater and runoff from the hills to water their fields and their gardens of date-palms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A7_2}Bunqaz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A7_2}Bunqaz sits at the mouth of the great wadi that divides the Jarjara Escarpment from the Jabal Tamar hills. Villagers sink wells here to tap the wadi's groundwater, using it to irrigate their olive groves.

Settlement.name: {=castle_A8.name}Surh
Settlement.text: {=castle_A8.text}Surh, the Rock, is a fortified town on a rocky promontory. It was firstly a colony of the Kannic. Old supertitions say that jinn spirits inhabit the forests near Surh. To this day, the Nahawasi, despite their faith differences, still remain distant from the forest depths. As of Kannic tradition, the town has ease of access to the sea and continues a strong naval tradition.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A8_1}Tamnuh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A8_1}Tamnuh sits near a large lagoon, cut off from the Perassic Sea by a sandspit. Villagers scrape clay from the shallow waters to sell to the region's potters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A9_1}Barihal
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_A9_1}The oasis-village of Barihal sits in a wadi amid the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. The land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A1}Quyaz
Settlement.text: {=1ImuW3My}Quyaz was once a mercantile republic that dominated the trade between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea, speaking the now all-but-extinct Kannic tongue, a relative of Nahasawi. But imperial hegemony slowly snuffed out its trade, and the rulers was taken over by mercenaries from the Nahasa. It came intermittently under imperial subjugation but today is a prized holding of the Banu Hulyan, a leading clan of the Aserai sultanate.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A1_1}Tasheba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_1}Tasheba lies on the western edges of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Fishermen venture out into the protected waters, gentle and calm for most of the year, for tuna and sardines.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A1_2}Baq
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_2}Baq slightly inland from the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, beneath the great granite outcrop of the Jabal Tamar. The seawinds bring the uplands here just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A1_4}Hiblet
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A1_4}Hiblet sits at the base of the granite outcrop known as the Jabal Tamar. Rainwater trapped in cracks in the rock is diverted to the village's date-palm gardens.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A2}Husn Fulq
Settlement.text: {=bnl7Va4c}Husn Fulq sits at the southeastern edge of the Caldea, the network of rivers and brackish lagoons linking the Empire to the Aserai lands. Fulq, also known as Phalcos, was a dark-faced mercenary chieftain who came from lands far to the south. He founded a fortress here and then parlayed its strategic location into a fortune, taking bribes from the Empire and then from the Aserai to switch sides. After 20 years of playing both sides back and forth he sailed home in a ship laden with gold, but many clans of the Aserai proudly claim descent from him, and the 'Tricks of Fulq' are a staple of many a bazaar storyteller's repetoire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A6_2}Lamesa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A2_1}Lamesa sits amid open plains and patches of dry acacia forest on the eastern shores of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Some of the Aserai's most prized horses graze on the grasses of this district.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A2_2}Abu Khih
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A2_2}Abu Khih sits along the Nahr al-Kals river on its way to its barren southern reaches. The surrounding lands, an ancient lakebed, are already becoming barren and alkaline, although date-palms still thrive.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A2_3}Hoqqa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A2_3}Hoqqa sits on the far east of the Aserai lands, on the Tiyagis river. The land is mostly desert-steppe. Barren most of the year except for scrub, it is covered in grass and flowers in the spring and is fine grazing for horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A3}Iyakis
Settlement.text: {=NFIYqaab}Iyakis sits in a cleft in the Jarjara escarpment, where the waters of the fierce but brief desert rains can be trapped and used for irrigation. For generations ago it was an autonomous outpost of the Empire known as Yachios, dominated by the Carasios clan. Fifty years ago however they saw the writing on the wall for imperial dominion in the southlands, and began intermarrying themselves with the tribes of the Nahasa. Today, known as the Qaraz, they take their places in the councils of the sultanate like any other family of the Aserai.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A3_1}Abba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_1}Abba sits on the edge of the deep desert, at the foot of the landward side of the Jarjara Escarpment. Runoff from the hills is trapped underground here, creating springs that sustain an oasis. Wheat thrives in the fields and gardens.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A5_2}Hunab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_2}Hunab lies in one of the wadis that cut beneath the weathered mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers raise horses here, taking advantage of the brief but lush crop of grass that covers the slopes in the spring.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A3_3}Bir Seif
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_3}Bir Seif is centered around a group of wells and pools in the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers dig down to the shallow groundwater layer for clay to sell to the potters of the Nahasa.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A4}Razih
Settlement.text: {=jXBnf2hQ}Razih is said to be the base from which Kannic explorers set forth to colonize the shores of the Perassic Sea in the centuries before the coming of the empire, the prows of their ships decorated with the intertwined vine leaves of the Kannic goddess of wealth, wine, love and war. Today, the Kannic tongue has been replaced by Nahasawi dialects and their religion is all but forgotten, but the symbol lives on, said to protect those who risk all for the sake of gain or glory.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A4_1}Qablab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_1}Qablab sits near a broad bay on the southern coast of the Perassic Sea. The low-lying coastline is well-suited to the construction of salt pans.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A4_2}Mussum
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_2}Mussum sits near the eastern coast of the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, where the Aserai deserts give way to desert-steppe with scattered acacia and scrub. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.

Settlement.name: {=village_A4_3.name}Labanabn
Settlement.text: {=village_A4_3.text}Labanabn lies on the desert-steppe mountains near Razih. Rich deposits here allow the extraction of pristine, white marble. The Kannic were the first to settle here, expert masons since eras past.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A8_2}Kuqa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_3}Kuqa sits at the foot of a range of low hills east of the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, where the Aserai deserts give way to desert-steppe with scattered acacia and scrub. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A8_3.name}Ynbet
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_A8_3.text}Perched on the Sarrani hills, Ynbet was once a traditional grape harvesting community of the Kannan. Associated with their matriarch goddess, the Vine Goddess, grapes thrive within the hillfaces of this region, which allowed the Kannan to master winemaking, the products of which they could sell for a high profit across the Perass.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_A8_4.name}Sadis
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_A8_4.text}Sadis is one of the first places in Calradia to have wood harvesting as its main economic activity. An ancient Kannan colony, the practice of collecting local wood has been maintained by the Nahasawi who know inhabit this land. Wood from this region sells for a high markup in the neighbouring Darshi and Nahasan regions, and thus was once the main source of wealth of the Kannan.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A4_4}Doqa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A4_4}Doqa is a fishing village on the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. Villagers sail out in feluccas to harvest perch that sometimes grow as long as a man is tall, keeping an eye out for the salt-water crocodiles which live in the local inlets and marshes and which compete with them for their catch.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A5}Hubyar
Settlement.text: {=IIMWPVhU}The inland city of Hubyar is said to be built on the ruins of a luxurious hunting lodge built by the decadent and cruel king Thuran, whom the patriarch Asera slew in vengeance for the enslavement of his family. This memory may explain the worldview of the fierce and austere Banu Qild, who hold the castle today and who detest all frivolity. But the scent of jasmine that can be detected on the night breezes here carries an undercurrent of temptation. It was here that the hero Nimr came to grief, caught in the chamber of a Banu Qild maiden and left hanging in a cage in the market until he perished.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A5_1}Mahloul
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A5_1}Mahloul sits in a broad valley between the Jarjara Escarpment and the Jabal Ashab hills in the desert steppe southeast of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Groundwater provides just enough water to grow crops for subsistence, while the village makes its money from rearing horses on the rich grass that grows in the Jabal Ashabi after the spring rains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A5_2}Liwas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A5_2}Liwas sits in a broad valley south of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Farmland is limited here, and the land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A5_3}Waltas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A5_3}Waltas sits by the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea, in lowlands well suited to the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=village_A5_4.name}Qanaar
Settlement.text: {=village_A5_4.text}Qanaar lies by the coastline of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The fishing industry here, started long ago by the Darshi in an attempt to colonize the Perass coasts, still supports Hubyar to this day.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A6}Sanala
Settlement.text: {=uO4dxCl8}The port of Sanala is the gateway through which the grain of the lower Damar has flowed forth to feed a hungry world. The Empire's periodic advances south of the Perassic Sea have usually been aimed at seizing this strategic prize. Although the legions were long ago forced to retreat, Sanala remains among the most cosmopolitan cities in Calradia, filled with merchants from many lands bidding for the lowest bulk prices.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_1}Mijayit
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_1}Mijayit lies off of the estuary of the Damar river as it reaches the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions of the Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_2}Hamoshawat
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_2}Hamoshawat lies on the lower Damar river, just before it reaches the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions of the Aserai lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_3}Jahasim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_3}Jahasim sits on the southern shore of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. The warm waters abound in tuna, bonito, sardines, and other fish.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A6_4}Nahlan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_4}Nahlan sits on the floodplain of the Damar River as it cuts through the Jarjara escarpment. This soil, refreshed yearly by the silt of the flooding river, produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A7}Askar
Settlement.text: {=GChIoZdd}Askar dominates the middle stretches of the Damar River, as it weaves between the bluffs of the Jarjara Escarpment. This region has been thickly populated for thousands of years, but the river is restless, and every few centuries leaps its banks and erases what comes before. This latest regional capital was an imperial encampment during their furthest penetration of the Nahasa several centuries ago, taken over by the Aserai tribes after the legions withdrew.

Settlement.name: {=village_A7_5.name}Damar
Settlement.text: {=village_A7_5.text}Damar takes the name of the Nahasan river, the Damar. Folks here grow date palms by the riverbanks, which grow in abundance. They worry about crocodiles more so than raiders, for they are deep within the Jarjaran maze, where armies seldom travel lately.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A9_2}Wadar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_1}Wadar sits in the rocky wadis at the inland edge of the Jarjara Escarpment, before it gives way to barren gravel plains and dunes. Clouds from the Bahr al-Yeshm drop their last reserves of water here in the spring and winter, giving the land just enough grass to support horse-rearing.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_2}Bait Hatif
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_2}Bait Hatif sits in the floodplain of the Damar river as it cuts through the Jarjara Escarpment. Rocky soil in this district limits irrigation, but horses thrive on the spring grasses of the hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_3}Mabwaz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_3}Mabwaz overlooks the Damar River as it weaves through the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers grow wheat and other crops in the silt of the river floodplain.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_4}Zalm
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_4}Zalm sits at the Scorched Gates, where the Damar river descends from the Nahasa desert and starts its journey through the Jarjara Escarpment. The silt brought by the river produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=village_A7_1.name}Hajar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_4}Zalm sits at the Scorched Gates, where the Damar river descends from the Nahasa desert and starts its journey through the Jarjara Escarpment. The silt brought by the river produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A8}Qasira
Settlement.text: {=J4bgNT0r}The legendary Queen Eshora, it is said, punished the jinn who were harassing her people by imprisoning them in one of the caves above Qasira, carving the mystical eight-pointed star into the rock to seal them in. She sentenced them to haul water from the depths of the earth, feeding the springs that gush forth from the rocks and which for centuries have irrigated the date gardens of Qasira and its surrounding villages.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=town_A9.name}Aigoisinaman
Settlement.text: {=town_A9.text}Aigoisinaman, the city by the holy water, is where the Siri first gathered. Here, it is said, Laha Mouei gathered his pride, on a rocky promontory by the Aman, and declared the land his terriroty. The Siri claim to be descendants from that pride.

Settlement.name: {=village_A9_1.name}Kappa
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A9_2.name}Etu Koir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A9_3.name}Kul Nokajor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A9_4.name}Esi Koir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=town_A10.name}Dawidipp
Settlement.text: {=town_A10.text}Dawidipp was founded long ago by the Siri, after the founding of Aigoisinaman. Dawidipp eventually outgrew Aigoisinaman and became the power base of the Siri queens, despite its sister city being the center of the faith. Countless caravans pass through and by Dawidipp, up and down the Aman, and the flow of trade feeds the city much like the riverbanks of the Aman.

Settlement.name: {=village_A10_1.name}Irk Kojir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A10_2.name}Irk Uun
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A10_3.name}Esi Ju
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A10_4.name}Kappa Kipti
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A8_2}Abghan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_2}Abghan sits by a small lagoon on the southern shores of the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Villagers here fish for tuna, sardines, bonito and shark.

Settlement.name: {=town_A11.name}Qalajib
Settlement.text: {=town_A11.text}Alongside Hubyar, Qalajib was an initiative by the Darshi to settle their northern borders, in hopes of arriving at the wealthy trade of the Perass. Centered in a wide valley and surrounded by tall hills, Qalajib has a very advantageous defensive position, with only one vector of attack and no possibility for a surprise attack. With the gathering of the Nahasawi by Asera, their hosts overtook the city, which is only accessed from the original Darshi lands through treacherous mountains paths known to sheep herders and not particularly effective for army movements. Such contact with the Darshi ways, over time, was one of the factors for the advent of the Sarranun culture, common in this region.

Settlement.name: {=village_A11_1.name}Xuaar Ard
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A11_2.name}Shqafit
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Settlement.name: {=village_A11_3.name}Waz Dashtis
Settlement.text: {=village_A11_3.text}Waz Dashtis was once a Darshian settlement. Mostly absent of good wood in their homelands, the Darshi eagerly moved many a worker here in order to collected the forest resources, sending it back home where it would be most valuable.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_1.name}Rimala
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_1.text}The capital of the silver dunes, Rimala lies deep within the easternmost escarpements of the Jarjara. An ancient metropolis of the Nahasawi, Rimala is cursed with a sea of sand dunes surrounding it. Its inhabitants, and those of nearby settlements, survive on the waters collected by the Jarjara, the life-giving rocks, for the rocks condense moisture which escape to its edges as small streams Despite this, Rimala has a bustling great market, thanks to the supply of grains and dates provided by the exceptional local wadis, as well as a thriving silverwares trade. Its tough nature proves to be a double-edged sword: not once the city was conquered by foreign masters.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_1.name}Hadiah
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_1.text}Hadiah lies deep within the Nahasa, south of the capital of silver. Here the Jarjaran stones collect great quantity of moisture into a bountiful wadi with deep red color. The exceptional quality of this wadi allows the Nahasawi to grow bountiful grains, much needed to feed the silver capital.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_2.name}Mashakra
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_2.text}Mashakra is a Nahasawi settlement south of Rimala, the silver capital. Here folks live at a long strip of wadis next to the Jarjaran stones. Water collects into these wadis and the ample sun allows for bountiful date palms. Such expert use of land in an otherwise dead environment allows the Nahasawi to feed their capital deep within the Nahasa.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_3.name}Fiddah
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_3.text}Fiddah feeds the silver capital more so than any foodstuff could: located by one of the Jarjaran escarpements, folks here mine silver veins that fuel the markets of Rimala. Though the settlement itself lies within a wadi, little food is grown here other than for self-sustenance.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_castle_1.name}Kafiyis
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_castle_1.text}Kafiyis, the fortress by the shadows. Strategically located, Kafiyis collects toll on the passing caravans, who often desperately need shelter and refreshment after the long strips of sand around Rimala. The fortress lies in a wadi, and thus requires no water other that collected by the Jarjaran rocks.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A5_2}Hunab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_2}Hunab lies in one of the wadis that cut beneath the weathered mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers raise horses here, taking advantage of the brief but lush crop of grass that covers the slopes in the spring.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_5.name}Hadba Mashiya
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_5.text}Hadba Mashiya lies between hills and mountains passes of the southern eastern Jarjara. Here the Nahasawi herd Nahasan sheep and goats, who feed on the grasses that grow by the cliffs of the Jarjara. This long tradition of the nomadic Nahasawi is also practiced by their settled kinsmen.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_castle_2.name}Qaws Anwar
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_castle_2.text}Qaws Anwar was long ago settled by an once nomadic clan. It is a typical Nahasawi fortress that has its back against the Jarjara, relying on it for water supply. The population around the area is thin and the land mostly unusable. The ancient tribe settled here after sighting a sign of the gods: a bow of light, rich in color, right next to the streaming water of the rocks.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_6.name}Ezbet Kirfan
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_6.text}Ezbet Kirfan lies on a wide and deep wadi. Surrounded by Jarjaran rocks on both sides, Ezbet Kirfan traps water that allows for life to thrive. The Nahasawi here herd Nahasan sheeps and goat, a traditional practice of the roaming Nahasan dwellers.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_7.name}Bait Alahin
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_7.text}Bait Alahin lies in a nook of the Jabal Ashabi mountains, bordered to the south by the deep desert. Villagers trap floods running down the hills during rare rainstorms, using the water to grow date palms and other crops. The Nahasawi here herd Nahasan sheeps and goat, a traditional practice of the roaming Nahasan dwellers.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_castle_3.name}Sharq Tariq
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_castle_3.text}The eastern path, Sharq Tariq lies east to Rimala, the silver capital. It is the easternmost fortification of the Nahasawi. Across the valleys it faces lies a vast section of the Nahasa, devoid of life. Nevertheless, the wadis at this here provide sustance enough for the fortified town to thrive, ever vigilant at whatever may come from the sea of dunes.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_8.name}Zahr
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_8.text}Zahr is one of the southernmost settlements of the Nahasawi, deep within the Jarjara. The moisture here gathers at the cliffs of the escarpment, a phenomenom the Nahasawi have mastered making the most use of. With ample sunlight and the red watered soil, folks are able to grow date palms native of the Nahasa.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_1_9.name}Amar Ard
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_1_9.text}Amar Ard lies upon one of the precious wadis of the southern Jarjara. The water gathers into a deep red soil that is suitable for farming, exceptional even for wadis. The Nahasawi have since long ago inhabited this land of great sustenance.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_2.name}Durqurba
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_2.text}The city by the shores, or so the Nahasawi named it, for it was the closest they could be to the Bahr al-Yeshm. Durqurba, once a small Kannan fortress, was the culmination of a large influx of settling Nahasawi, before the rise of Asera. Here they struggled against the Kannan, who strove to control the whole of the Perass shores, and controlled this region between Shurelit and Quyaz, both of Kannan origin. Here the Nahasawi found green pastures unlike much of their other settlements, which combined with the water from the Jarjaran rocks and Perassic rains, allowed them to thrive into a great city.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_2_1.name}Gaara
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A3_1}Abba sits on the edge of the deep desert, at the foot of the landward side of the Jarjara Escarpment. Runoff from the hills is trapped underground here, creating springs that sustain an oasis. Wheat thrives in the fields and gardens.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_2_9.name}Shawaatis
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_2_9.text}Shawaatis lies hidden away between the palm trees in a rocky formation by the coasts of the Bahr al-Yeshm. It was once a fishing colony of the Kannan which was replaced with the waves of Nahasawi that came from the desert.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_village_2_10.name}Zitis
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_village_2_10.text}Uqba sits alongside the Perassic Sea. Villagers trap rainwater and runoff from the hills to water their fields and their gardens of date-palms.

Settlement.name: {=jarjara_castle_4.name}Sharq Hammaam
Settlement.text: {=jarjara_castle_4.text}Sharq Hammaam lies amidst various Jarjaran rocks and wadis to the east of the Damar river. Plenty a palm tree grow in the region, due to the small streams coming from the rocks. Although barely inhabitable for most, for the Nahasawi it presents an opportunity they would not pass.
